column8: Kaudulla National Park for elephant sightings
column11: The modest reserve, centered around a reservoir, is a sanctuary for a diverse range of wildlife and is especially known for its large elephant population. We observed more than a hundred elephants roaming and feeding on the lush banks of the reservoir. During our viewing, a male elephant that had been following a female suddenly turned, using its trunk to forcefully butt two safari jeeps. The second butt was so powerful it lifted one side of the jeep off the ground. This viewing experience was both captivating and thrilling.
If you want to see elephants: go to Kaudulla National Park. You‚Äôll see loads of elephants who are not afraid to come near. A very magical experience!

column8: Unforgettable Elephant Safari at Kaudulla National Park,
column11: Visiting Kaudulla National Park was an incredible experience! üêò We saw herds of majestic wild elephants up close in their natural habitat, along with beautiful scenery and birdlife. The safari was peaceful, authentic, and truly worth it

We were recommended this Safari by our driver whilst travelling around Sri Lanka and were not disappointed. Getting into the park was quick and easy. Within the first few minutes of entering the park, we saw our first elephant and then as we rounded the corner we were in awe of the herds that were gathered around the park. Amongst the many elephants, we witnessed many babies (just weeks old), mothers and the odd lone male all in their own natural environment.  Our jeep driver was very respectful of the elephants and kept his distance, allowing us to take in the truly fantastic moment. Additionally, the park was a lot quieter than we imagined. Driving around we also noticed other animals and a variety of bird species. This was one of our highlights of travelling around Sri Lanka and recommend this to anyone debating whether to visit or not- we actually preferred this safari over the Yala one.

Much quieter (tourist wise) and cheaper than Minneriya and still gathering elephants- more than 100 with 2-3 week old babies at foot. also saw several bulls, many birds. Unbelievably good tip from our driver to come here rather than Minneriya!

column11: Joing with " Trvel with Dimma " the couple from Usbekistan has done a Wild Safari in Kaudulla national park.They lucky enough to see the unique Tusker of this jungle name call Esala as well as many about 200 gang.Its amazing ride with them to enjoy the adventurous destination like this in Srilanka.

There seems to be no limit on tourist jeeps going into the park at any one time. On our mid-Aug visit, us tourists outnumbered the 100 or so elephants gathered at the reservoir. And phalanxes of jeeps almost blocked the path that the elephant families use to go from the forest to the reservoir. The herds had to pass through a gap in the wall of jeeps, perhaps deliberately to channel them so that tourists could take photos close up. Quite unethical. Seemed to stress out the elephants: one indignant mama raised her trunk and blasted the jeeps while her baby ran away. Apart from the Asian elephants, the ‚Äúsafari‚Äù as a whole was underwhelming, with scarce wildlife‚Äîsaw some buffaloes, a serpent eagle, heron, couple of grey langurs. If you‚Äôve been on African safaris, lower your expectations!

What s beautiful park but managing it at front gate is really disgusting. We had top wait over 1 1/2h at the gate to get tickets. 80% those visitors were foreigners and they were grumbling.  Early and on line booking facility is a must.  It is the tour guide /drive decides where to go as it is a optional to Minneriya.  They know where the elephants would be on that particular day with previous days experiences.  We have seen just over 100 elephants with around 8 tuckers.  Also saw a eagle feeding on another bird.. on our way back we gave a way to a elephant to cross the road but another jeep came and blocked the path so elephant has no way to go and went back. This was very cruel.  Jeep drivers discipline should be addressed as well.

They were approaching the jeeps and the elephants were camping wide, they have complete freedom to go where they want not as in other safaris. Even on the way to the hotel there was a road in the area. It was an amazing experience, seeing so many elephants in a herd and in freedom. We recommend going in the afternoon from 16 as recommended by our guide as that is when you see them well!
Recommended to visit this park, rather than Minneriya, as fewer trucks but still plenty of elephants and a big park - it didn‚Äôt disappoint, saw many elephants on a nice drive along the lake.

During my trip through Sri Lanka, I visited Kaudulla National Park for a jeep safari ‚Äî and it was hands down one of the most beautiful experiences I‚Äôve had in nature. The park itself is surrounded by lush greenery, open grasslands, and peaceful scenery. From the moment we entered, the excitement built up. After a short ride through the forest, we spotted our first elephant‚Ä¶ and then another‚Ä¶ and then a whole group! üêò We saw babies, mamas, and even a few lone bulls, all moving gracefully in their natural habitat. It wasn‚Äôt rushed or touristy ‚Äî it felt authentic, calm, and respectful to the animals. Our driver kept a good distance, allowing us to watch without disturbing them. Watching them in their natural home, completely free, was such a touching and unforgettable moment. What made the day even more special was the kindness of the owner of our hotel, Sigiriya Cashew Palace Resort, who personally took us to the safari. He made sure we had a wonderful experience from start to finish. After the safari, he even stopped along the road to buy us fresh coconut to drink while we watched the sunset. Such a simple gesture, but it meant so much. If you‚Äôre planning a trip to Sri Lanka and want to connect with both nature and kind-hearted people, I highly recommend visiting Kaudulla and staying in Sigiriya. This day left me with memories I‚Äôll cherish forever.

We saw a huge herd of elephants up close‚Äîsuch a magical moment! The safari was extraordinary, Beautiful scenery and plenty of wildlife. A must-visit if you‚Äôre in Sri Lanka!

Kaudulla National Park located in central Sri Lanka. This wildlife sanctuary is famous for its stunning reservoir that attracts a plethora of wildlife, particularly the hundreds of Asian elephants that roam freely within the park. The park's unique selling point lies in its impressive elephant gatherings, known as "The Gathering", where herds of these majestic creatures congregate around the reservoir during the dry season. Watching these gentle giants interact with each other against the backdrop of lush greenery is an awe-inspiring sight to behold. Visitors can embark on safari tours through the park and witness not only elephants but also a wide array of other exotic species such as sloth bears, sambar deer, and various bird species. Kaudulla National Park truly offers an unforgettable wildlife experience like no other, making it a must-visit destination for animal lovers and nature enthusiasts alike.

After a while watching one mum and her baby, our driver turned the jeep on to drive away, this did sadly spook the mum who then started to run at the jeep. Thankfully we got away fine! Such a brilliant experience and would highly recommend! We did an afternoon Safari (1:30 - 5pm) in August.

This is NOT a bad review of this particular park but of the poor management of tourism at the Sri Lankan national parks, and a complete lack of respect for the elephants & other wildlife who call the place home.  It seems there are no limits placed on the number of safari Jeeps pouring into the park at any given time. Sadly humans continue to be the biggest threat to wild animals and that was very clear during our visit today. Yes we saw lots of elephants BUT it was so overcrowded with Jeeps  gathering around the elephants and at one stage there was a family of elephants making their way over the the lake when they couldn't get through the barrier of Jeeps. One of the elephants became upset as they were obviously protective of their babies and found the hoards of people/Jeeps a threat. These are endangered animals and they deserve a helll of a lot more respect than we are currently showing them. I regret joining this tour, as did the other 3 in our group, it is distasteful and I would recommend giving it a miss until there are regulations s in place that actually consider the wellbeing of these beautiful animals and restricts the number of cars flowing in. At one point I counted 50 Jeeps in one area, where is all that entrance money going? It's definately not being spent on protecting these amazing animals!

Kaudulla or Minneriya is the obvious question when one is in Sigiriya area. Guides and jeep drivers decide on know positions of elephant herds and water level in the area. Our Jeep safari suggested Kaudulla, so off we went. We did have a few sighting of peacocks, deer, birds, monitor lizards, but these parks are for the majestic Asian elephant the largest mammal on land. After a bumpy ride through the greens we came across a vast expanse of grassland and so many elephants. There were everywhere, near us, ahead of us & everywhere we could see. This was a large gathering of approx 350 wild elephants. Our driver said that there are more baby elephants this year than last. This is the best place in Sri Lanka to see wild elephants in such a large number. Park ticket costed us LKR 14800 for a group of 6 and jeep charges were LKR7500

There are 3 national parks in the vicinity (Minneriya,Kaudulla and Eco), with elephants travelling across all 3 of them, which is why it is best to check with locals (hotel owner/ tour operator) to confirm which park the elephants are in. We checked with Rana's information counter and were informed that the elephants were in Kaudulla, so booked a safari here. We booked the afternoon slot and entered the park around 3.00 P.M. We saw a lot of elephants and big herds of wild buffaloes soon after entering the park. At the lake, we saw a big herd of elephants, including some cute baby elephants. Overall, this was a great experience and we thoroughly enjoyed watching elephants so close and in their natural surroundings. On the cost - we checked with a few operators and ones we approached through the hotel and our driver quoted prices around 30,000 LKR (inclusive of tickets and the jeep). We then went to the main road and checked with a  few tour operators who had their offices there, where we found Rana's information agency, and booked the safari for LKR 19,000 (inclusive of tickets and the jeep). An alternative would be to check the prices of the jeep only and book tickets yourself. This will allow you to negotiate the price of the jeep (the tickets will cost the same as they are issued by the government). The only issue with this is that you will spend quite sometime in talking to various people and negotiating rates, while you potentially save 1 - 2,000 LKR, so the savings might not be worth the time spent).

We were really lucky to have witnessed nearly 200 - 250 elephants around this time of the year and also saw a few variety of birds too

Honest review. Before visiting Kaudulla, I had said that I would be happy to see three elephants! I had done quite a bit of research regarding the safari's and elephant sanctuaries in Sri Lanka and both Minneriya and Kaudulla were the ones that came up as the most ethical while others just seemed a bit sketchy or disrespectful in terms of the space given between the jeeps and elephants. Sometimes you just have to go and see it for yourself and so we did. The national park is a big land and the elephants are entirely free to wander through Kaudulla and Minneriya without direct interaction with people. If you have a good camera, you're in for a treat. We saw hundreds of elephants! Yes, there are a lot of jeeps but I felt like the drivers kept a respectful distance at all times and even to one another so as not to hog all of the space. We were often quite far away from the elephants and only close if the elephants were coming toward us or passing by us so I'd recommend buying a good zoom lens if you don't have one. My camera had an unfortunate accident in some torrential rain in Ella so I had to make do with my phone but I still got some really great pictures and even better memories. All in all, this was a major highlight of a full-on trip and I would definitely recommend it. I think it cost us around $60 USD each and I felt like we got our money's worth.

Every attraction we visited, foreigners had to fork out between 20 times to 100 times more than the locals.

Also if you are Lucky you might be able to see snakes and crocodiles aswell.
Enjoyed a Safari in this park about an hour away from Cinnamon Lodge Habarana. It was exciting to see the elephants roaming free along with birds, mongoose, deer, cattle and monkeys.

An afternoon visit was recommended as having the best chance of seeing elephants.  So enough time to visit Polonnaruwa the morning have lunch and head to the National Park. Whether Kaudulla or Minneriya will probably depend on where the elephants have been sighted recently.  Minneriya was deserted as we drove past as the elephants had been favouring Kaudulla. The cost of the park entry was around US$100 for 4 of us.  Then there is the jeep and driver which our guide organised.  A total of about US$150.  So an expensive 3 hours, but we did see lots of elephants with the lovely backdrop of the lake.  And although there were many in the distance around the lake we were also able to get very close to some. By the way, there are probably as many people and jeeps as elephants!  It is a popular activity, so you certainly won't be alone (see photo)

Unique Incredible wildlife Spectacle! Three of us, my wife, our grandson and I were picked up at 2.30pm on 20th July 2019, by our safari jeep from TripAdvisor sponsored Lakpura LLC.  The journey from our hotel in Habarana to Kaudulla park entrance took about 40 minutes.  After the driver of the jeep, Asela, purchased our entry tickets, we entered the park at 3.30pm and drove on a bumpy road through the dry evergreen forest.  There were over 100 jeeps witnessing this epic spectacle of elephants. As we neared the reservoir, we saw a long line of elephants ambling along towards the centre, towards the water.  As they neared the water, they became impatient and hurried on faster.  It was a fascinating spectacle to see such a large group drinking at the same time, first sucking in through their trunks and then delicately elevating the curved trunk to drop the water into the open mouth. As the water level in the reservoir recedes during the dry season, grass growing on the banks attract elephants from a vast area around.  It was an incredible sight to experience them eating this lush green grass on the banks.  The big elephants first displace the soil with their fore legs to loosen the grass.  Then they collect them nimbly with the tip of their trunk and dash them a few times on the ground patiently to remove the soil before gently curving their trunks to put the cleaned lump of grass into its pink coloured large mouth.  Little ones trod behind their moms, learning the intricacies of retrieving the lush grass from the ground.  Other groups of elephants were frolicking in the water.  I photographed two youngsters having a mock fight. The reservoir is the centre of all wildlife within the park. It is a paradise for birds. We saw large numbers of water loving birds - ducks, painted storks, egrets, ibis, pelicans, Cormorants, lapwings, herons and other species.  We saw a few fish eagles too.  There are deer and other wild animals.  Visitors however, come here mainly to see the elephants foraging and frolicking in large numbers. This elephant gathering takes place annually either at Kaudulla or close by Minneriya reservoirs during the months of July to September. Before deciding on the venue for your safari it is best to enquire from the safari company where the elephants are. This "Elephant Gathering" is an unique, incredible spectacle for wildlife enthusiasts. We go there at least once a year to witness this great spectacle and display.

In April the Minneriya and Kaudulla reservoirs are full.  By August with the release of water for irrigation, the water level recedes and fresh grass starts to grow on the banks nourished by the sediment left behind by the retreating waters.  Elephants from close by and far-away congregate here to feed on this succulent fresh grassland.  This phenomenon had been there for centuries after the construction of these reservoirs in the 3rd century AD.  Elephants do come quite close to the jeeps and did not appear to be aggressive.  Let us hope that the human-elephant conflict would not disturb this eco-system in the years to come! On a daily basis, during the season, over 300 jeeps enter the Kaudulla Park with tourists, to see this great spectacle.  The road approaching Kaudulla is being upgraded resulting in slow traffic movement.  Though we arrived early at around 1500 hours, we had to stay in the queue of vehicles for about half an hour to get our entry permits.  Once we entered the park it was more peaceful.  If you are a photographer you should station yourself so that the elephants are lit by the golden sunlight.  The jeep drivers are experienced and park themselves in optimum positions to allow you to witness and capture these moments with your cameras. We shall go there again next year too!!

This is a good place to see elephants, though minimal other wildlife. I‚Äôd call this more of a elephant watch drive rather than a safari. Also, as we were leaving it looked like it was getting very busy (5pm). We were lucky enough to be on our own before then.

Kaudulla National Park is amazing and good on you for choosing to see elephants in their natural habitat instead of the poor captive elephants in Sri Lanka. People who drive the jeeps don't say anything to prevent very common head slamming that happens when safari-goers are stepping out of the jeeps. Please remember to take off your sun hats and watch out for the led pipes of the jeep roof. At least 5 in our group of 10 in two seperate jeeps accidentally slammed their heads. I ended up with a concussion. If this was in the US, several companies would have already been sued, so precautions would have been made! Here, no ones warns, there are no signs and yet, we heard from many who made the same mistake and ended up with very painful heads. So watch out. Please take a safari jeep into a park like this instead of riding elephants or seeing them in festivals and pageants and temples or hotels. We went in August and saw at least a 100 amazing elephants and baby elephants!

We were lucky enough to be here at the time of year when all the elephants congregate ‚ÄòThe Gathering‚Äô. We saw over 100 elephants on the plains by the water hole. It was an awesome sight! In the herds were babies only about a week old and a big male ‚Äòtusker‚Äô elephant. You really do get close up with them. There are lots of jeeps; too many as it seemed to stress the elephants. We weren‚Äôt expecting that after the less busy Udewalawe National Park. The terrain is very rough; be prepared for a very bumpy ride!

We saw at least 90/100 elephants. It is quite expensive but totally worth it. My only recommendation will be to choose a time when there are not many cars. It gets really busy and there are far too many jeeps but it is incredible to see the elephants in the wild.

Our family group of 4 adults and 2 children (9 & 11 ) spent a week in the Dambulla area and used SP Vijith Kumara for an afternoon safari. We were very impressed with the amount of elephants and other wild life he was able to get us close to not only in the national park but along the way. Also he did a great job in taking us to animals away from all the other jeeps. He is a very nice friendly guy and enjoyed talking to all of us providing local knowledge, tips and useful information . After this tour we used him for the entire week for various other sightseeing trips and even to take us places for dinner which he was more than happy to do for us. We did a second morning safari with him which was also brilliant. We would highly reccommend using him for any safari or sightseeing needs in the Dambulla area. He has a facebook page as follows: Jeep Safaris Mathisha Dambulla. Check him out.

Surprised by the large number of jeeps in the park at the same time. Does not appear to be any road rules or driver courtesies and is a free for all when passing/overtaking. Plenty of elephants to see but roads/paths are well worn with dips and pot holes. Good viewing from open air roof when standing up in the jeep. Not the most exciting safari but OK if you can tolerate the hustle and bustle of all the traffic.

This is all down to timing. The elephants had migrated to here, an minneriya, so this is where the action was.  There must have been 100 jeeps swarmed around a similar number of elephants.  Still a worthwhile safari, although the scenery is not as stunning as at minneriya.  There also appeared to be fewer birds of note.

A $100 US dollars was paid for this safari. It wasn't so much an animal safari, as a jeep safari.  There were hundreds of them, and  all we saw was about 6 elephants, and even that was hard jostling with the other vehicles to get to see them. There was nothing that we hadn't seen before.  Our driver thought a peacock or a lizard was something we hadn't seen before. The majority of animals we saw were cows, we didn't even see a deer. And when we got back to our hotel our driver wanted a tip!! Do not waste your money One of the elephants we saw could hardly stand up and walk.

You have to hire a safari jeep for this trip,they will open up the roof and allow you to watch the surrounding. You have to travel in a muddy harsh route. Along the forest you will find peacocks, monkeys, and variety of other birds. When you came closer to tank, you will see parade of elephants walking towards forest. Very small calves to giant tuskers were there. Safari jeeps go little closer to elephants but you can't touch them.

I had been looking forward to the safari but my heart sank when we spent nigh on an hour queing up with loads of other jeeps and buses just to enter the park. However things did improve once we got inside the park and the traffic thinned out. The highlight off course was the elephants and their babies but we also saw water buffalo and a few birds, don't expect to see much other wildlife tho'. Great experience but would be much better if the number of jeeps were limited to a certain number at any one time, think the wildlife would appreciate it too.
It was amazing. Muddy and bumpy road due to rain. Better to visit after in the evening after 3 clock. There are lot of elephants and baby elephants.
Great safari saw lots of elephants and some monkeys on the way out of the park.  There are many jeeps and some are less considerate than others where respecting the animals is concerned.

Kaudulla national park is an amazing place to examine the life styles of animals like elephants and tigers. We entered at the evening to the park and that time is the best time to view the herd. We examined several activities of elephants like cuddling and bathing. Baby elephants were playing with their parents but they were rejecting to have bath at the end of the day.üòÇüòÇ It was a sunny day but we didn't feel tiredness because of these cuties.üêòüê¶üêØüêÇ

We saw around 100 elephants, including 5 babies. Also quite a bit water birds. Also monkeys. Views in the park are very nice. It is a beautiful park! Indeed a lot of jeeps, at least 50 driving around. Didn't really bothered us though. We paid 90 dollar for 2 persons, 3h trip. All in all worth the money.
Our entrance fee was 1670 rupees for 2jeeps, 12 adults, 6 children. I think entrance fee for foreigners is much higher than local. Each jeep charged 3500. We got it near the entrance.

We were luck and felt privileged to see the annual "gathering" where literally hundreds of elephants make their way to the lake in the centre of the park. It is a truly amazing experience to see so many and so close up The only downside was that there were at least 100 jeeps doing the same thing and we really felt for the elephants, trying to make their way to the water, but often blocked by the jeeps. It didn't spoil an amazing sight though

Probably wish we had not gone now. Yes, the hundreds of elephants were amazing to see, but the experience was marred by literally over 100 jeeps surrounding them. The elephants must have been so stressed. I feel Sri Lanka is going to lose it‚Äôs amazing assets by complete lack of eco tourism. We stayed for only 30 minutes as I felt so guilty. Paid $110 for two in own jeep, but would happily have joined others if there had been that option.

Our driver arranged the safari. He told that the elephants are not in mineriya Park today. We visited Kaudulla park near Habarana. We saw minimum 100 elephants in the nature. We paid 100 usd for two adult and 1 child for private Jeep. We started at 13.30 and turned back at 17.30 when we said it is enough.

I was promised elephants when I did an afternoon safari and was not disappointed! I had been planning to visit Minneriya, but was advised Kaudulla was better for the time of year. There were so many elephants, including a young baby. There were some other animals in the park, but the elephants were the main focus. Unfortunately, there is no limit to the number of jeeps allowed in the park, so there were LOADS! Fortunately, I had a brilliant driver who went and found spots away from the big clusters of jeeps, but who still respected the elephants' space. A wonderful sight if you get the chance.

OK there are many jeeps in the park  as mentionned in many comments but you cannot expect to have this gem all for yourself... However many jeeps with 2 and sometimes 1 person, the park should force jeep operators to pool together more passengers, it would reduce the flow and increase their margin (but decrease revenues of drivers as they are paid a fixed amount per jeep, whatever the number of people in it). Beautiful park with lots of elephants at this time of the year, we saw one group with >30 elephants and another with >100 elephants, plus eagles, deers, foxes, peacocks. Great day with the kids !

column7: Bay of Plenty Region, New Zealand
column11: Fabulous. Every August the elephants start their migration. Our driver knew his job and introduced us to 4 large herds meandering through the Kaudulla National Park. At one stage we were the only vehicle in our guide's secret spot and we're surrounded by about 70 elephants including 1 month old babies suckling on their mothers. Late afternoon with an experienced driver. Our day in the park was our highlight of our Sri Lankan holiday. A truely remarkable and humbling experience. One elephant up close and personal makes my heart jump. Three hundred sets my soul on fire.

Absolutely amazing trip, it was breathtaking to see the elephants in the wild. Our guide was brilliant and knew the correct times and places to go to. There were a lot of cars but knew the areas and places to go to. It was my favourite day of the whole trip- memorable for all the family

Ok so there are a lot of elephants but really so what if they are so numerous if jeeps by the dozens block the roads . I liked Udawalawe where it was more sensitively managed with a greater range of terrain and wild life This was a low pount of my holiday

We had a great afternoon in the park and saw lots of elephants. However The place was far too crowded. There were dozens of Jeeps everywhere, this cannot be good for the wildlife. The driver seemed to be wanting to rush through the track as fast as possible to take on his next batch of tourists. The noise of the engine going at 40MPH is enough to drive animals away by the time you turn up to a good spot, so what is the point! When asking questions, he seemed to have little knowledge about animals. As for other natural parks in Sri Lanka, the financial interest is greater than the animals' interest it appears. We did take some nice pictures and the children were happy to see so many elephants but a quieter, closer to nature experience would have felt a lot better.
It's amazing elephant gathering. Lot of babies near the lake ground of Kaudulla. They eat , walk ,palm and bath. Thank you Kalum safari for wonderfully experience

Enjoyed seeing the lovely majestic elephants at Kaudulla National Park! We were told by a few local people that Minneriya National Park didn't have as many animals as it often does this time of the year so we took the recommendation to go to Kaudulla instead. We weren't disappointed with the park! It was slightly cheaper than Minneriya (although I can predict the prices may go up as they are even doing up the roads leading up to the park probably for more tourists). It's also not as busy as Minneriya can get which is nice but the main reason I can't give five stars is due to the level of tourism now at all these national parks. It's lovely to see these beautiful animals in their wild habitats, however I can't help but begin to see these national parks as a zoo or large tourist safari park like you get in western countries. There are so many jeeps that at times it looks as though the elephants are closed into spaces due to the jeeps all around them. This isn't all the time which is fortunate and seeing elephants (around 60 on the day), monkeys, plenty of birds and even a crocodile was amazing! I would definitely recommend Kaudulla National Park and it's worth taking local advice as many people work in tours and can recommend what the animals are doing at that particular time of the year (they are likely to charge you the same jeep hire price regardless of if you go Minneriya or Kaudulla). Enjoy the amazing animals but let's hope they begin to limit the number of jeeps allowed in at any time, otherwise this incredible national park will look more and more like a cruel zoo. Recommend: Doing your research on credible touring companies and jeep hire before you go. Otherwise you may end up booking a firm who over charge or try to squeeze more money from you through pressure sales or tips at the end. Otherwise enjoy!! :)!!

We visited the park as part of a teip company and spent the afternoon in a Jeep. The roads into the park are being resurfaced and it takea quite a while to drive up there on a bumpy road to the park and, amongst so many other Jeeps going to the same place. At first there is a road cutting through some trees and dried up river bed so there are some chances of seeing some wildlife along the way. We saw chameleons, a crocodile and a cheetah. Once we got to the plains, we saw a small group of elephants immediately. Following that, there were two large herds to look at whilst they were grazing. They came so close to the vehicles and it was lovely to see them interacting in the wild. Lots of Jeeps in the same place though which seemed to crowd the elephants at times. No shade whatsoever when standing in the Jeeps so be sure to take hats and wear suncream!!

The elephants are the main attraction here and you can visit via a jeep safari.  The elephants move around, so you might see them at Mineriya instead. The jeep ride is bumpy but the driver knew where the elephants were, at the lake and very used to the 50+ jeeps! so we were able to get very close and got some great photos. Best time to see them is around 3pm, so allow an hour before that to get to the lake. We saw a huge herd of around 100 elephants, some as young as a month old who very well protected by the older ones but were playful and chasing the birds. There were also water buffalo lying down in the lake to cool off and a huge variety of birds in the shallows. Definitely the highlight of the trip. As with many other lakes in Sri Lanka, it is an artificial lake, with the damn causing a fairly large reservoir which retains water even during the dry periods as now (July 2018). The national park covers all the area of the lake plus a sizeable margin around the edges. Although the park is run as a very commercial enterprise, that is preferable to the alternative where the native population don't value the native wildlife.

Wonderful  experience and a bit of an adventure. Two memorable safaris were done, which were the best days of our holiday. The moment we entered the park it was just magical! We were lucky enough to see herds of wild elephants, fantastic. I will never forget this National Park. Saw herds of Elephants, Eagles, Foxes, Water buffalos, & loads of different birds. We had a good driver and a guide who spotted things we would never have seen.

Yes, Kaudulla is busy with safari jeeps. But for a good reason: there are lots of elephant herds to be seen at close range. Definitely worth an afternoon safari! We appreciated it even more than our visit to Udawalawe.

We came with Kalum Jeep Safari on their recommendation. We saw lots and lots of elephants. Our driver also pointed out smaller animals and birds. There were plenty of vantage points. The day we went there were lots of jeeps but our driver got us away from them and our photos were just elephants. If it is elephants you want to see then this park will reward you with excellent viewing.

We did the afternoon tour for 11,000 rupee for a Jeep with 4 people. We saw hundreds of elephants who all seemed so relaxed and not bothered by the fact there were also hundreds of jeeps in the park. We also saw crocodiles, birds, buffalos, deer and monkeys. The elephants were definitely the highlight! We couldn‚Äôt believe how many there were. Highly recommend the National Park.

The elephant is my favorite animal so I was excited to see them! However, there were jeeps after jeeps after jeeps in the park which really took away from the beauty of experiencing the elephants in their natural habitat. I gave 5 stars for the elephants. Unfortunately I'd give 1 star for the jeep experience. There were over 200 jeeps there! The poor elephants shouldn't have to be exposed to so many at once! There should be a limit of jeeps allowed into the park as this is their home and we're visitors in their environment. The elephants deserve their home to be a sanctuary of peace and guests should be limited.

This is the most hideous excursion we had. The way into the park it was crowded we thought. There were approximately 50 jeeps waiting to get into the park. When we left, it was rush hour London never had! The Safari is just a visit to the zoo in a Jeep. No question you are going to see elephants, they are there in herd of 50 together. We saw three of those herds. Magnificent animals and easy to photograph, but what a shame we are doing this to them.
Not sure what to expect - but it turned out to be one of the high points of our 3 month South Asia trek! Elephants and lots of ‚Äòem - very up close and personal - simply spectacular!
We visited Kaudulla National Park in July and had the most amazing time. The elephants were the main attraction and we were not disappointed as they were there in force.

An exciting journey with around 150-200 elephants that come near our Jeep. We also saw some buffaloes and different kinds of birds. The only thing is it was a crowded and dust coming from other cars so at the end everyone was tired on the way back. Will recommend to anyone.

We came here spontaneously on the recommendation of our hotel after another planned activity fell through; we hadn't heard much about the park beforehand so didn't know what to expect. We arrived at about 2pm and spent several lovely hours watching herds of elephants grazing and playing in the water: it was incredible to see. There were also lots of birds, buffalo and crocodiles to be seen. We did notice the park getting busier as the afternoon went on, but the jeeps were always very respectable and kept their distance from the animals. We were mesmerized, and highly enjoyed the experience.

We went in the evening around 3.00 pm and we were able to watch more than 150 elephants around the lake, 1 crocodile and buffaloes as well. It was crowded since this is the season but our driver was able to manage through a different route avoiding the usual jeep traffic. We saw so many elephants migrating to the forest from the lake and many baby elephants with eye-catching activities. We heard that there were few elephants at Minneriya and I think it is a good decision we made by visiting Minneriya these days. We went with Sarath getting into his jeep from Habarana town and his number is 076-6111527.If you looking for a safari jeep, you can call above number.

Visited during rush hour (after 16h). Over 200 jeeps intimidating and surrounding herds of elephants that - logically- get frustrated. This led to several clashes as there seems to be no rule/agreement amongst drivers. Complete mismanagement this, should be stopped!!

Great way to see tje wil elephants migrating from the forest to the water. Go in the afternoon from 2 o clock on. Avoid late afternoon or early evening for reason of extreme business with 4 wheel drives and jeeps

Kaudulla national park is a great place to see elephants grazing near the lake in the afternoon. We had a large safari vehicle which was perfect for 5 of us and we left our guest house in Habarana shortly after 2 pm. It was nice to get to the park before 3:30 pm because by 4 pm it was crowded with other jeeps, with everyone keen on seeing the elephants. We had about 2 hours of elephant watching here...really cool to see them in the wild and undisturbed by our presence.
Using a guide and special viewing vehicle we had a good safari. Saw many elephants in their natural habitat. Water buffalo and monkeys are there too

Having visited Minneriya Wildlife park the day before this was further away from the hotel in Habarana & there are major roadworks along the way. However the park was a lot quieter and there are plenty of elephants to see at close range including a few only weeks old that were having a mud bath. If you like elephants this is a great trip.

Really beautiful National Park but completely spoiled by the amount of Jeeps visiting. The elephants were, for the most part, unphased by the volume of traffic going past. On the plus side, there was loads of wildlife to see!! Aside from the majestic herds of elephants we saw a wild fox, peacocks, monkeys, buffalo, cows, stalks (and lots of other birds I can‚Äôt remember the names of), and to my delight I caught sight of a huge kabaragoya (Asian water monitor lizard) having a paddle in the river. I would definitely recommend going to Kaudulla (or any of the national parks) for a ‚Äòwildlife safari‚Äô not just an ‚Äòelephant safari‚Äô.

Had a safari to see elephants in early July. We left all the organising to our car driver from SLD tours (Sri Lankan driver tours) and he talked to locals about where the elephants were best at the moment. We went with driver/vehicle 45 from United Jeep Safari Association. (Not sure if every operator or driver is registered with this or not, you can see the yellow stickers on some but not all jeeps. Our driver was friendly and happy to point out things along the way, we ended up in Kaudulla while most tours seem to go to Minneriya. Total cost 5500Rps per person and that included the park entry fee. We saw elephants, eagles, crocodile, water buffaloes, cranes, Ibis and lots of smaller birds. In total around fifty mostly female elephants and young, they seemed not too bothered to see us. There were a variety of other Jeep‚Äôs around at the same time and all went pretty close to the herd, the elephants were well able to say if we were too close and all the jeeps backed off. Elephants are why must people come to this area and the tour was a good one. Looks like there are so many tours drivers hanging round Habarana that you don‚Äôt really need to book in advance. It‚Äôs 4x4 city and everyone wants to offer a tour. We were happy with our driver and United Jeep Safari Association. Got to do a safari if your in Habarana or anywhere near these parks. We have also passed wild elephants on the roads this week too.

Situated about 190 km from Colombo, Kaudulla National Park is dominated by the Kaudulla Tank built by the sister of the famous King Mahasena who was the creator of the Minneriya Tank. The folklore of the creation of this tank is very interesting. The park is also situated on an elephant migratory path (an Elephant corridor) , which makes this park even more interesting. The park sits in between the Somawathi National Park and the Minneriya National Park. The road network of the park is about 16 km, but lack basic visitor facilities. Trackers have to obtain from either Girithale or from Habarana. Like Minneriya, Kaudulla offers a good chance of getting up close and personal with elephants. In October, there are up to 250 elephants in the park, including herds of juvenile males. There are also leopards, fishing cats, sambar deer, endangered rusty spotted cats and sloth bears. The best time to visit is from January to March and, less reliably, May to June.

Saw lots of wildlife - birds, hawks, eagles, cows and of course elephants. We were really lucky and saw lots, and some young ones. Definitely worth it. Our driver was really nice and patient, he stayed until we were completely satisfied. We must have been a few hours.

It is also the most beautiful and the place where animals can walk freely, and the park is home to the highest concentration of leopards in the world, and it is also an important sanctuary for Sri Lankan elephants and aquatic birds. Monkeys, crocodiles, and other critters run around the park‚Äôs grassy plains and forest areas.

We were on a tour of Sri Lanka as part of a Trip A Deal group tour and our guide, Lakmal, suggested we go into the Kaudulla National Park and try and find wild elephants, which are now protected and roam freely in the National Park. This tour was ‚Äúan extra‚Äù, to fill in a few hours of ‚Äúfree time‚Äù we had one afternoon. What an excellent suggestion as this turned out to be probably the best highlight of the trip. All of our group of 10 elected to do the tour and we met up with our safari guides and were transferred into 4WD‚Äôs. It was a bit of a trek to get to the National Park, taking about 40 minutes to get there. Once we arrived, the safari guide opened up the roof of the 4WD allowing us to stand and take in all the sights. We entered the park and had our eyes peeled in search of the elephants. We saw many birds, even a crocodile sunning itself on a rock but no elephants. There were traces of them (elephant poo), but no elephants. We drove around for about 30 minutes along the road through the forest and then we came out onto the open fields to a huge lake. We drove along the dirt tracks adjacent to the lake and turned a corner and WHAM‚Ä¶...straight into a heard of about 30 elephants roaming freely eating the grass and foilage. It was a sight we will always remember. There was a big bull, who when he saw us became a little spooked and began to charge at us. Our driver reversed up quickly and the bull backed off. He eventually moved and we were able to pass by. To cut a long story short, for the next 90 minutes or so, we drove around this part of the National Park seeing 5-6 herds totaling more than 100 elephants. We would just stop, turn the engine off and watch these huge majestic animals in the natural habitat. It was a great experience. There were many other tours doing this as well, with up 10 4WD‚Äôs parked at one or two locations. But the elephants didn‚Äôt seem to care at all‚Ä¶..in fact, they often roamed by within a few metres of the vehicles. If you get the opportunity, make sure you do this‚Ä¶.you won‚Äôt be disappointed.

Our tour company had originally rranged for us to visit Minneriya national park but following local intelligence our guide informed us we were better visitng here to see the elephants.  Boy we were not dissappointed.  Our guide had arranged a 1968 jeep to take us round.  Our driver was excellent and obviously new the park vry well and pointed animals out to us as did our guide.  There are lots of jeeps queing to get in as the entry and exit times are restricted.  This was a very enjoyable visit and certainly gave us a taste of what we could expct when visiting Yala later on during our tour.

If your back can handle the rough ride there and back it‚Äôs well worth it. Probably saw 100 Elephants of all sizes in the wild feeding and having fun. We took a video of them charging us in protection of a one month old baby. It‚Äôs the most exciting footage I have ever taken.

We had been searching for these marvellous creatures for more than 3 hours. The scenery was a-maz-ing and the anticipation & excitement would grow more and more with every sighting of fresh poo, every footprint, every track into and out of the jungle and every broken branch or tree pushed over BUT there is nothing NOTHING that can top seeing a creature happy and safe, free in an environment it's so perfectly suited to whilst being surrounded by creatures of it's own kind. I have seen a few elephants in my time but I have never been so blessed to see them in a National Park and see them visibly happy.¬† And then when we went to another place in the park we got to see them come out of the jungle in numbers so vast I had never expected such a sight.¬† I could have watched them for hours.¬† ¬†Brought to tears I was. A valid mention also goes to the water buffalo and bird life a-plenty.

Place was teeming with wildlife... went late afternoon around 3pm.. we were driven in a Jeep. 3 hours just roaming around... be careful when u book. We knew we overpaid by at least 3 times. But the wildlife made up for it..
Got to see lot many elephants.  It was raining heavily and many safari jeeps around. we saw many elephants from close range. a very memorable elephant safari.  Enjoyed.
Very nice trip to national park, almost four hours. I saw elephants, pickkoks, Egels, wild cows a lot of different birds. Yes it was very crowded almost 100 Jeeps was the same time in the park.

I am a single woman, which usually is no problem to travel. However, in this case, the guide was a bit weird and I almost felt scared at a moment when he stopped in the middle of nowhere (and no animals), and seemed to want to have a little break for no specific reason and to take some pictures of us, the car, etc. He could hardly speak a word of English and had no clue about wildlife. The park is beautiful, but they use it as a 4x4 amusement park, destroying everything, driving everywhere. Interestingly, it was not a sunny day and we saw only 1 elephant in the park. There were  many other cars entering at the same time, but I am not sure where they went because  we went around the lake without crossing path with more than 2. The whole thing costed me $80 for 3h, from Habarama, and there was no way to discuss the price.

Yes the drive is bumpy but this adds to the fun. We loved it. Saw loads of elephants as well as many other animals including water buffalo, eagles, egrets, painted storms, peligan, elephant stork and loads more. Strongly recommend.
OK so they call these rough vehicle trips SAFARI, but they are not great. You do have a good chance to see a large group of Elephants, if little else. Worth your money...not really.

Our 4x4 drive jeep was VERY bumpy as the roads are very, very rutted but in the end I felt it was worthwhile just to see a very large herd of elephants of all ages including a couple of males facing up to each other over a female with he big lad chasing away the younger male. The winner's wee offspring seemed very pleased with his, I presume, dad when the latter returned. We were surrounded by 4x4 jeeps so it is hardly a quiet safari. lots of birds but little other mammal wildlife apart from the odd monkey. A few goanas by the side of the "road" ignored us. We did see some impressive sea eagles.

I was a bit skeptical of the safari beforehand, particularly given the number of vehicles all heading the same way. However, once we got through the first 10 mins to get to the lake we saw loads and loads of elephants all making their way through the park. There were a lot of other tourists but our driver was good at getting us to a position so that we were close enough to take pictures and feel away from the crowd. He also managed to take us around the lake to an area with no other vehicles where we saw a group of 6 elephants by themselves. There were plenty of other animals and birds to see but the elephants are the main attraction.

We had to book a jeep for the national park safari, as cabs are not allowed inside the park. The jeep was open roof and we enjoyed the ride. There were no animals in sight and we started wondering if it was a right decision to pay that amount of entrance fees and come here. Unexpectedly it started raining and we hastened to pull up the waterproof cover over the jeep and got completely drenched in the process. It was fun. Soon we came up to a place which was crowded by other jeeps, only to discover a herd of elephants ahead. The rain soon started coming down in full force. Even though we were enjoying the sight of elephants, I am not totally sure how much the elephants were actually enjoying. The jeeps seems to have surrounded them from all possible directions and they seemed to be stuck between the river and the jeeps. They seemed to be confused in which direction to move, because they kept changing directions. But soon their leader got them going and the heard soon disappeared from sight.

Instead of visiting elephant orphanage I decided to take a jeep safari to this place. A unique experience to observe elephants in their natural habitats, you can feel that they are at home there and we were just visiting. Quite crowded with many jeeps.

We paid 5000 rps for a 2 hour keep safari of the park. This included the entrance price and also a guide. We mainly saw many types of birds and very soon came across a whole herd of elephants - around 30 of them! What a beautiful site it was. There were quite a few other jeeps around but only really noticeable when we reached the elephants- they were otherwise pretty distant. I preferred this safari over yala as it‚Äôs not so busy and I much prefer elephants to leopards.
We reached The park around 3p.m there were a large number of safari jeeps at the gate any way we were lucky to see many elephants including a magnificent tusker .

column7: New Forest National Park Hampshire, UK
column11: We were really looking forward to seeing the elephants again after a great experience in Uda walawe NP. We were told Kaudulla NP was the place to go over Minneriya NP as this was where the elephants were. So we went off in a jeep and basically joined everyone else... the poor elephants were so encroached upon. It felt more like a zoo car park than a safari. The kids loved riding in the open top jeeps but that‚Äôs about as good as it got. Something has got to be done to manage the NP. It‚Äôs only a small area for a NP and we left feeling a little sad for the elephants. Not sure we could recommend especially if you have a chance to see elephants elsewhere.

Had an amazing visit to this park. Recommend organising with a local company as they know the times the elephants generally go to the water - for maximum viewing.  There are literally hundreds of elephants and if you are the type to just want to sit and watch elephant behavior this park will exceed expectations. Be warned that there is a sea of other vehicles also watching - we did go over New Year so traffic was more, although also great to see locals enjoying the wildlife. Don‚Äôt expect an African type safari though, there will be elephant and maybe something else, but you will be lucky to see anything else.  The point is the elephants though, and they did not disappoint.

This park is located on the Habarana Trincomalee road and is about a 30min drive from Habarana town. If you have a jeep or cab with 4 wheel drive and high road clearance then you can go on your own. Or else you will have to rent a safari jeep. The park is small compared to Yala so you can do a full safari of the entire park in 3 hours and a half day safari would do. The park is open from 6am to 5:30pm but the best time to visit is after 1pm when the elephants come out to the lake to bath and drink water due to extreme heat. (weather) The safari jeep cost for a half day (3 hour) tour is Rs. 3,500/- and the entrance ticket for 2 locals is Rs.840/- and 2 foreigners is around Rs. 6,000/- All the safari jeeps have a open hood (roof) or no roof so make sure you have sun protection, either sun screen or a hat unless you want to get sun burnt due to extreme heat. There is a lot of dust inside the park so good if you can wear a face mask. There are also many water birds and eagles in the park but I don't think anyone has spotted a bear or deer inside the park. Make sure you avoid weekends or long holidays when visiting the park or else you will end up photographing a load of safari jeeps instead of elephants due to the crowd!!!

We went here one afternoon to see some elephants in their natural habitat. We got picked up from our hotel, had a good few hours driving around the park and then got dropped back to our hotel. We only saw three elephants, however that is no criticism of the park. Anyway, we did see a lot of other interesting wildlife as well. We would rather risk not seeing any elephants in their natural surroundings than go to an elephant sanctuary where they are chained up for the majority of their lives. Seemed to be a lot of jeeps there, many more than we were expecting. That was the only issue we had as it spoilt the views of the park.
Good alternative to mineriya where there are less jeeps and more elephants to see per tourist. Long loop with good trails. Lots of elephants plus peacocks kingfisher monkey etc
We went in a jeep safari and saw many animals and even babies with their mothers. It is must visit in Sri lanka.

A game drive in Kaudulla proved to be one of the highlights of my trip to Sri Lanka. Arrival at the park did not look promising, with countless safari vehicles and heaps of people coming and going. Once inside the park, the mayhem ceased and we could enjoy the nature. After a pleasant drive through woodland, the road emerged to a huge grassy plain with a lake in to distance. It turns out, the entire plain is underwater during the wet season, which explained the muddy tracks we had to negotiate. At first, all we saw were birds and domestic cows but that quickly changed. Over the course of our game drive, we saw over 200 elephants in several herds, including a number of calves. Despite all the vehicles, there wasn't any crowding, with each vehicle allowing ample time for observation, often at very close range. Even in four trips to Africa, I have never seen so many elephants in one place. Don't miss it!

Animal lover that I am, this was my favourite experience of our trip to Sri Lanka, despite being very unlucky and only actually spotting a pair of distant elephants in the park. We arrived at the park from Polonnaruwa for the afternoon safari starting at 2.30 pm. We were a little overwhelmed by the swarm of jeeps (apparently up to 400 are allowed in the park at any point), but as soon as he could, our driver turned away from the pack, took the roof off and set off into the trees. It was amazing fun to drive along standing on the seats looking out over the roof of the jeep. Our guide and the driver were experts at spotting all sorts of birds (including a pair of lesser adjutant stork which are quite rare, and a pair of eagles) and wildlife. He was extremely patient, stopping and approaching as close as he could for us to take pictures. When it became clear that we would not spot any elephants inside the park, our driver took us out onto the main road to track down a family of elephants at their regular spot. I wish he hadn't in the end as my heart broke when I saw mama elephant eating paper litter :( :(

This was the best trip for us (me especially as elephants are my favourite animal!). We were picked up from our hotel in the jeep and it didn't take long to get there. When we arrived our driver put the hood down on the jeep and pointed out various things of interest along the way......wasps nest (huge!)/monkeys/deer/birds until we reached a family of elephants. What an amazing privilege to see them in their natural habitat. I thought that was it but we carried on through the park and met up with a herd of at least 50. Some of the babies were only a few weeks old. How protective they are their young shielding them from our prying cameras. It was quite emotional. We did not feel rushed and stayed for about an hour just mesmerised by the herd. If you get a chance to visit this part I would definitely recommend it. We also visited an elephant orphanage earlier in the week and there were stark differences in both but equally fabulous.

The visit to Kaudulla was sensational. Our driver and guide superb. Driving to the grass plain took us along a winding road, and during that time we came upon a protective mother. She instinctively charged our vehicle, however it was more show than anything. We weren't to know that - cowering in the back of the truck. When we entered the main grass plain we were surprised with close to two hundred elephants all hanging around chomping on grasses. We were told that three herds usually come together just before dusk, but we were very lucky in the fact that it was only midday. How majestic and calm they all were. Amazing! So much wildlife in this park. Water buffalo, eagles, monkeys, painted storks... We were a little horrified when departing the national park, as there were over one hundred vehicles in or driving into the park. The young lads I was with counted them! Please make sure that if you get the chance to get out of your vehicle, to pick up at least three pieces of plastic. I made a quick pick-up of about fifty pieces in a ten by five metre area at the edge of the lake.
Perfect place to get closer to elephants. You ll see a herd of 50-60 jumbos. On the other hand I felt the jeeps are going too close, violating territory of wild life.

We reallt wanted to see elephants in the wild. We have seen the lot, but always ik capture. We din't get dissapointed. Go arround 14.00 hour and you see big groups of elephants at the lake. Go earlyer and you dont die by the heat. So make your choice. We seen more then just the elephant and i think a trip to this park is big add on your vacation.
It was amazing safari in kaudulla national park. We saw many wild elephants and many wild animals. Memorable experience in sri lanka

There are 2 national parks in the area.  At the time of our visit this was the best to visit to see elephants as the other park had too much water therefore not enough grassland for grazing.  Worth the trip.. absolutely.  Yes there are a lot of jeep safaris doing the same thing, but they all seemed to be doing the right thing. We got excited at the sight of the first single elephant only to go around the corner to see herd after herd, probably in excess of 300.

We took a jeep from a company I wouldn‚Äôt recommend - Atika.....comfortable jeep but the driver did not engage with us at all, was on his phone at times, and when we made a request to stay longer than 90 mins he had a ‚Äòpaddy‚Äô. He drove fast and returned to same group of elephants we had just seen. I have been on some African Safaris and there is much more respect shown the animals. I wonder if there is any control on the number of jeeps at any one time. We enjoyed the animals and birds and hope the NP put in something to respect the animals.
But also lots of people (jeeps) so don‚Äôt expect africa safari style. But surely nice to see the elephants, specially during sundown with the whole family.

Our initial plan was to visit the Minneriya National Park, but upon arrival we were informed that since it was the off season (Minneriya Lake is being filled with water for cultivation during this season and the elephants are migrating to the Kaudulla area temporarily), we better visited the Kaudulla National Park if our intention was to see hundreds of elephants.(hell yeah!) Thus, the Park authority provided us with a safari jeep from Minneriya on wards and damn it was downright fun! It took us about 45 mins. to travel to Kaudulla (off road-short cut) and the journey was all worth it. We chose the afternoon to visit the park (around 2 pm), which is the ideal time to see elephants by the lake,  and the queue was quite long at the ticket booth. (they could've added at least two counters!) Finally, when we got to the Kaudulla Lake, we were blown away by the number of elephants who leisurely roamed around! We couldn't count of course (were busy taking selfies with wild elephants,no big deal), yet I am sure there were about 250 of them! That was one fantastique sight! Loved every bit of it <3 **If your intention is to see only elephants, Kaudulla is the ideal place for it. If the intention is beyond just elephants, well then Minneriya it is (with reference to the national parks only in Dambulla area, not in the entire country).
Wow! We loved our safari here, we saw so many elephants and the park wasn‚Äôt busy. Our driver Chandla was fantastic with our son. An extremely memorable afternoon.

We booked a private afternoon safari tour for two persons. After we entered the park we already met our first elephant, and not far from there we were lucky to see many small groups of elephants most of them had many baby elephant around them. We then arrived near the lake in an open field where we were very excited to see more than 100 elephants spread all over the field in bigger or smaller groups eating, playing, and babies making noise. Some of them were even showering so we had the chance to get many pictures of the elephants in many positions while they were doing their normal activity. Some of the elephants were tuskers, and as far as we know we were lucky to meet them because it is not very often to meet tusker elephants in Kaudulla. Besides elephants we were also very lucky to see many birds (i do not know exactly the name, and there were too many to write them down). When we left we were so lucky that we saw a huge crocodile outside the water, doing a sun bath just before sunset.

What a fabulous afternoon. Best to book a tour early afternoon as when we were leaving around 4.30, there was a massive queue of jeeps coming the other way, evidently to miss the heat. We did this through our hotel, the Vaana Resort and were picked up from there. Around 200 elephants out and about wallowing in the lake with 2 tusked and lots of babies. Boy, they‚Äôve really got their work/life balance sorted!

Just breathtaking! Elephants of every size as far as the eye could see.  The journey by jeep isn‚Äôt all that comfortable as the track leaves a certain amount to be desired but our jeep was skilfully and carefully driven and our backs survived the ordeal! What s memorable afternoon.

Kaudulla was the first safari of our Sri Lanka trip. we met our driver and started the safari. the moment we started our jeep to leave, i saw 3 Malabar pied hornbills fly. the hornbills landed and we ran out of our jeep. the hornbills jumped around until they sat for a minute before flying. we made our way into the park. we arrived at the park and heard a call. we looked on a tree and found a juvenile crested hawk eagle. soon after that we saw a nest of Asian predatory wasps. we went to a lake and saw an Indian roller at the top of a tree. we we saw many painted storks and even many of the rare lesser adjutant stork. after that right next to the lake we saw another jeep that had broken down for 2 hours. we helped them but they couldn't do anything. our driver was  about to give up and turned right and saw an elephant at the lake. we immediately drove there. we looked at the elephant for 30 minutes. we drove away and saw a peacock dancing until an elephant chased it away. after that we saw 2 elephants fighting from far away. after that that we saw a male elephant that pooped and peed before walking away. after that we drove to an area where many jeeps were. then we saw gray big rocks there from fa. we went close and saw 30 elephants. our driver was good, however, another jeep got in between a mother and a 5 day old calf. the elephants started trumpeting. we were late as the park closes at 5 pm. we got out of the park at 5:30 pm. on the way back we saw our elephants cross the road.

We did an afternoon safari here and yes there were an awful lot of other jeeps, and it didn't feel like you were out exploring the world on your own or anything but seeing so many elephants in their own environment was amazing really great experience.

You never miss a chance see hundreds of elephants during your visit. We didn't pre-book the safari. Our hotel " Wildescape - Polonnaruwa" arranged that. Best times for the safari is either early morning around 6.00 or after 1.00 pm. We reached their around 2.30 pm. The road is bumpy but enjoyable. within 20-30 minutes, we saw the first herds. There were so many elephants with number of calves which is a wonderful site. They were on the banks of the lake and enjoying bath. There were many big ones and tuskers. We went so near to them and it was quite safe as the safari Jeep driver knew how to approach them quietly.It was a wonderful sight to see them crossing the lake in herds. We spent about 2 hours in the park and saw peacocks, buffaloes and eagles too. A must see attraction if you see visit Polonnaruwa or Habarana areas.

we have been in this park because it is very easy to watch free elephants. we were satisfied as we saw 50 elephants busy in their daily chores. even families with children. depending on the season you could be diverted to the nearby minneriya nation park. the opposite happened to us but there are no problems as the elephants move freely between the two parks depending on the rains. your guide will suggest you the best.

We didn't pre-book. We stayed at Vaana Resort, a boutique hotel in Habarana and they organised everything.  It was absolutely awesome. The elephants move from one park to the other and during our visit they were mostly at Kaudulla. Again, we got local knowledge from our resort. We went in the afternoon and saw more than 400 elephants! Feeling so very lucky to have seen these majestic animals in the wild. Lots of  new born calves as well.

Yes it indeed was.... Bumpy roads,offroad driven trips being soo closer to hundreds of ginormous friends is not a very common experience and must add it was a very pleasant one for my family and me If you go in the everything you can see almost all the elephants around the lake.. And the chances are high to find nice peacocks and very many birds too

My two young daughters wanted to see Elephants and plenty of Elephants they saw. We saw 3 seperate herds near the lakes edge including baby Elephants. We entered the park at about 1.45pm and within 10mins came across the first herd. Had a big bull come pretty close to the jeep we had to get out fast. We drove about 5mins more and came across another herd approx 40-50 Elephants. At that time I counted 12 jeeps. After 45mins of watching various groups within the herd we moved off. There were more jeeps arriving. We found the third herd approx 30 Elephants not far away and we were the only jeep at that time. Some of the bigger Elephants came up to the jeep only 10ft away, a little scary but wandered past, then more jeeps arrived. We also saw Water Buffalo, Eagles, Monkeys & a snake in a tree. We spent approx 2hrs in the park, well worth it and saw more Elephants than expected.

Practical tips:- - the elephants migrate between different parks so hopefully your driver will find out which park will have the best viewings - our driver organised the tour with a local company. we were charged 55 US  dollars each which includes the entrance fee and jeep - we went at approximately 3.30pm. There was a bit of a queue to go in but it wasn't too bad. It did start raining heavily at the start. - it is very bumpy. We found it easier to stand. - there is a toilet at the beginning. Obviously you can't use the toilet once the safari has started. - we saw around 400 elephants. We were so close to them, it was amazing. They seemed really calm and undisturbed by us. Saw a group of them going to cool down in the water. -it does get very hot so take plenty of drinks and also cover your head to protect from the sun.
Amazing safari !  Really enjoy the trip - to be  surrounded by elephants and managed to see them pretty close up.  Real experience in Sri Lanka :)

We paid 5000 for our driver and jeep and 2500 each to go into the park. Best time to go is after 2pm. There may have been a lot of other jeeps but it didn't detract from the elephants. You easily got loads of photos without jeeps and there were even a few jeeps making a rapid get away as elephants charged them (no real danger though). Check out the photos.
Saw 200+ elephants during our three hours in the park, absolutely amazing. Although the variety of animals here is less than Udawalawe, there were so many more elephants to make up for that!

Went on an evening safari to this National Park & had  the ost uncomfortable rough ride ever & saw very little wild life except elephants. We see more bird life on our balcony in Sydney! Not worth the money & discomfort.

If you want to see lots of elephants and do not mind being surround by 50 other jeeps, you will be happy there. Don‚Äòt expect a real safari though where you rather discover animals, it is more that you are taken to main spot where most elephants are and that is it. If you want to discover other animals you should tell the safari guide beforehand and choose one that decently speaks English and knows the animals and where to find them. We also saw elephants bathing in the jungle river, axis dear, buffalo, monkeys, a lot of birds.

Hundreds of elephants wandering around in big herds and a few other animals besides - water buffalo, cattle, storks, pelicans, eagles etc. It's about a 30 minute drive north of habarana. Make sure your guide doesn't just zoom straight in for the elephants - they're fairly easy to spot - and points out all the various other wildlife around. The ride is very bumpy on and off road in the park so be prepared!

this wasnt really what we expected there were an awful lot of jeeps in this park and all converged on the lake to see lots of elephants , i counted 30 jeeps all surrounding the elephants ,we thought udawalawe was a more natural experience ,
Mainly there were elephants and few peacock and buffalos but going in a Jeep to see them and the view was a great experience
Good jeep safari amongst the elephants. Really interesting with lots of photo opportunities. Buffalo and birds in the national park too. Really enjoyed the experience

We collected our jeep at Cinnamon Lodge and were told iit was over 50 years old - well it felt that way driving around the park. You will see the occasional elephant whilst driving around and many birds but at the end all the jeeps converge on the lake to spot the herd of elephants. Almost 100 grazing along the banks unlike Africa where you will see smaller groups. Tour lasted almost 3 hours so good value for  money. Took so may photos, need to review on our return. . .
Spent three hours one evening on safari. The evening was well worth while because we saw lots of hers of elephants making their way to the lake. Amazing experience and not to be forgotten.
We wanted to visit Minneriya national park but got the recommendation to go to Kaudulla instead. Saw literally hundreds of elephants. Simply amazing!
wonderful opportunity to see herds of elephants behaving naturally, youngsters playing, adults supervising . fantastic photo opportunities
Quick and lots to see. Very manageable in a couple hrs. Good guides and lots of elephants, birds and sun!

We chose Kaudulla National Park because we met people a few days ealier that had a fantastic expereince. We arrived in Habanara by bus with our 3 children at about 2.30pm and a helpful tuk-tuk driver found us a cheap room then helped us find a jeep driver. We paid 21,000 LKR for a 3-hour jeep ride from town.¬† We left at 3.30pm and arrived at the perfect time to see about 80 elephants grassing and bathing.¬† We also watched as they walked between all the jeeps to get to the fresh grass on the other side of us.¬† Utterly spectacular! I know that some people have complained about all the jeeps, but there were a lot less here than at other parks that we considered.  We also know plenty of people who spent a lot of money at other parks and never saw Elephants at all.  So I think it's important to keep a perspective about the popularity of this park unless you have loads of money and can arrange a private tour somewhere else.

We went on the jeep safari you couldn't really do it any other way it pretty rough tracks. You get to see so many elephants its so moving plus a raft of other birds, animals etc.  The guides choose the best park for the time of year and in Jnauary this was clearly the best. Watch out for the hoards of other jeeps though.

Before visiting Sri Lanka i made some research about where you can see the elephants in a natural enviroment. I found a lot of posts about Kaudulla and how it wasnt as crowded as the other places. Man was i dissapointed, this was like a mayhem of jeeps. Perhaps 50-100 in a very small park stressing the elepgants out totally. It was like a safari in a zoo.

An amazing afternoon spent in a jeep watching large herds of elephants going about their business of washing, eating and dusting themselves with their young, in the wild. At times they were as close as 3m away, it was very special.

Great ride to see the elephants. The tracks are bumpy so hold onto your phones and don't place them in your lap! Very dusty with all the other jeeps driving around so wear sunnies and be prepared to get dirt on your face. I loved seeing the elephants around the lake but there are so so many other jeeps around it's a bit of a circus to get through. We saw beautiful elephants, peacocks, monkeys and some wildebeasts. Fun experience. The cars are jeeps with car seats welded onto the back ute, no seat belts required. Hilarious but fun!

We had a two hour jeep safari, which actually lasted an extra 30 minutes. It is the elephants you come to see. Our tour started at 1.15pm and we were a little concerned that this was the wrong time to do this. There were only 4/5 other jeeps out with us so it was not crowded in the vast plains. We were not disappointed as the elephants were there in large numbers, including a baby elephant only a week old. There must have been 30/40 elephants together. It was fascinating and we were able to get pretty close, which was good as we had left our binoculars behind at the hotel! When we finished and returned back to base at 3.45pm there were loads and loads of jeeps and tourists getting ready to leave. Far far too many. We were so pleased that we had gone out at 1.15pm. We also saw some birdlife, including some eagles which were very impressive.  But it is all about the elephants.

We went on a safari jeep to this park because the jeep owners all said they elephants could be sighted only at Kaudulla and not at Minneriya this time of the year - probably they already saw them. The road was extremely bumpy and we did spot a crocodile, a peacock and an eagle on our way. Very close to a water body, in a large open space there were about a hundred elephants, including little ones. they were busy grazing; not sure if they were bothered by the presence of so many jeeps. A little distance from them was a herd of water buffalos, also grazing. NIce to see the animals in the wild.
The best place to see elephants. I saw nearly 150 elephants. The driver was good and we spend around 3 hrs in the park.
Elephants by the hundred lots of rare birds and a safari experience do die for. Good for couples or families. See nature at ease

The experience is really lovely. But, these vehicles who rush at the elephants needs to know to maintain the right distance and give the elephants their space. When we were there, a herd of elephants wanted to crossover to the other and a bunch of jeeps were right in the middle blocking the way and each and every jeep trying to give their guests the best possible instagrammable picture. We need to understand that while enjoying the view of these amazing creatures we need to maintain the sanity and give them their space to move freely. #natnzin
Went in comfortable jeeps that kept our brood of 5 under 12's and a MIL of 80 safe and comfortable whilst still being able to enjoy the views.

Kaudulla greatly exceeded expectations !  It was a bumpy but lovely ride in from the highway through forests where we spotted many birds, deer and a small crocodile on the way to the park .  When we got to an open grassy plain with a large lake nearby -in a steady drizzle - we spotted a few elephants at the edge of the dense forest. Once the rain quit ..... the elephants came out to eat, wander and goof around!  We counted two groups of about 40 animals and a third group of 20 and various strays . There were many Other Jeeps present but everybody stood off a bit and let these majestic animals attend to their business if eating drinking and socializing .  It was a day that will be with me the rest of my life!

Even though it was cold and raining torrentially, I really enjoyed the safari. There were groups of elephants strolling about and even more jeeps clustered around the elephant families. Don't expect to see more than elephants on a jeep off-road ride and you'll leave satisfied.

Just a short ride from Habanara this is an easy 4 hour package where you'll get lots of close encounters with elephants. The driver knew where to find them and constantly positioned us in perfect spots to watch and photograph. It's a bumpy ride in the jeeps so be warned! Visit Rana's Travel shop in Habarana to arrange it rather than use your hotel as it will be much cheaper. See reviews of his services.

Went on this Jeep Safari. Was our first time on a safari! Was exciting.. would have been happy if we saw more than just elephants. But nevertheless it was a memorable experience! Such peaceful animals! Until one actually started chasing the keeps away!

Our trip to Kaudulla was wonderful! After searching for about half an hour we stumbled across a group of approx 100 elephants, including lots of little ones some only a few days old. We were able to watch them from our jeep, as they moved around us and ate. We then moved on to another group, again of more than 100. This was so special seeing them in a natural environment, and all the jeep drivers and tourists seemed very respectful of the elephants too. Make sure you check with a local which national park they'll be in as they move freely between this and Minneriya park.

What an amazing place. We did a safari here and were not disappointed. We saw all sorts of birds and animals and our guide was very knowledgeable with a great eye for spotting the wild life.
