We saw the elephants in the water and having sand baths a truly amazing experience. Best to go about 1pm as best time to see the elephants at the water.

We visited Kaudulla yesterday and it was amazing seeing all the elephants!  There were a herd of about 50 and we were able to observe them from very close.  It was amazing to be able to see them graze and interact.  There was a pregnant female in the herd as well as a tiny baby elephant!  We were absolutely awed by their beauty.  We did the evening safari, after 3 pm when we saw them.  We also see peacocks, crocodiles, a hornet‚Äôs nest and eagles!

Fabulous trip organised from guesthouse. Picked up and taken to where the herds had migrated to in the parks. Spent a couple hours just watching the elephants. Jeeps kept to the roads and are only supposed to park on sode of road to preserve the grass. The elephants seem to like grazing near the roads instead of at a distance which was great. Baby elephants everywhere! We tipped the drivers at the end for a good job done.

Our driver guide arranged the safari tour for us and upon picking us up to take us to the jeep driver informed us there were more elephants in Kaudulla than in Minneriya this particular day. Thus, it was onto Kaudulla. The trails, as you would imagine with safari, are a bit rough and the jeeps are open air - it was FANTASTIC! We had our 23 month old with us and part of the reason we ended up in Sri Lanka and not Africa on this trip was that we could safari with him in Sri Lanka, and Africa is much more difficult to find child-friendly offerings. After entering the park and driving for a bit we saw a few monkeys. Further up the road, our first sighting of elephants in the wild - amazing! Overall, during the 2 hours we spent cruising through the park we probably saw a total of 80-90 elephants. Some in different herds, some solo, and even a mother nursing her baby. It was an awesome afternoon and I highly suggest this to anyone. At least on our particular day as well, there were very few other jeeps. We maybe passed in total 10 other vehicles, non of which distracted from our experience!

My wife Julie had said before that all she wanted to do was to see an elephant up close & in the wild. Well we saw 2 different herds and her day was made when the huge bull elephant in charge of the first herd turned and walked past our jeep at a distance of less than 30 yards.... lots of pictures. Saw some buffalo and birds, but its the elephants that you go for. Apparently there are crocodiles and rumoured to be leopards, but I think you would be exceptionally lucky to see these. Don‚Äôt be put off that there are dozens of jeeps as the animals ignore them.  Great couple of hours

We did a Jeep safari with Akita safari.  The Jeep was comfortable and the driver was an excellent animal spotter.  The elephants were amazing about 100 of them at the water hole.  The only draw back was there were at least 40 jeeps all watching the elephants.  Some of them people were noisy and not respectful of the animals.  We went at 2 o‚Äôclock and it was very crowded.  Our driver did a good job of anticipating which way the elephants were going to move.  Takes three to four hours and the road is very bumpy.

We travelled with a fellow called Asana in a real 4 wheel drive vehicle (unlike most others which were regular 2 wheel drive jeeps) - just the two of us. Asana knew exactly where the elephants were. We left early - 1.30 -  2.00 pm found the elephants a herd of over 80, watched them emerging from the jungle for their afternoon feed. We were there with one other jeep - it was magical and then, completely spoiled after jeep after jeep arrived - there would have been over 30 jeeps there in the end. We had had enough left early too to go and look at different birds in the park and spot a crocodile.  Our guide Asana knew so much about the elephants and wildlife - he was respectful in his approach and not a cowboy as we drove through the plains to get to the elephants.  He was also very knowledgable and told a lot about elephants, how to identify then as a male and female, breeding etc. I don't think Asana advertises widely - our driver organised for him to take us - I do have a photo of his phone number which i can send on request.

I was staying in Polonnaruwa and through my hostel did a jeep tour here to see the elephant gathering. I visited in late August which is a good time from what I gather. I saw a ton of elephants, more than the rest of my life combined. I wasn't the only one as there was a few dozen jeeps here but it all still worked out to have great views of the elephants while not really interfering with them. If you want to see lots of elephants I'd recommend a tour of here.

Did eventually see over 100 elephants, after a bumpy ride for approx. 30 mins. Plenty of jeeps on the safari; must have been at least 40 where the elephants were. This did sometimes result in jeeps blocking good view.

We went on this trip with our guide we had for the week ( feb 18) .we went out in a jeep with a local guide , jeep sizes vary we were only 2 in back of ours .The tracks are abit rough so be prepared to bounce around abit , but thats part of it ! We did see alot of widelife , crocodiles in the river at the start , varity of birds , monkeys , water buffalo but the best bit was seeing all the Elephants, we sat for couple hours watching them swim , fight and play there was around 150  Elephants it was lovely to see. If your in this area put this on the list .

This was a spur of the moment safari and glad we did. Cost of this was ¬£55 for 2 people and we were told that in Feb this was a good park to visit for the elephants. We had a great guide, new all about the wildlife and birds names and seemed to really care about the animals. He came from United Jeep Safari in Habarana (0773155044). All vehicles here are 4 wheel drive Word of caution - you have to shut out of your mind the number of jeeps around literally dozens, all doing the same thing in the same direction. There are lots of elephants and when you see them all of the jeeps congregate around. We were fortunate to get a great view of them crossing the river.

Our driver recommended us this national park as we are on the way from Negombo to Sigiriya. And true enough, yes, there are many elephants and baby elephants in this national park. There were also peacocks, eagles, many types of birds, crocodile and some monkeys. We got a guide who helped us spot many animals amongst the bushes. It costs us USD 60 each (not sure if we got ripped off as this was not part of our itinerary). We also managed to get up close to some elephants and baby elephants. They didn‚Äôt seem to be bothered by our presence - could be because they are used to humans. Overall, really good visit and worthwhile! Expect a really bumpy ride as there are many potholes on the road. (All photos taken by iPhone)

Took an afternoon safari here after our guide told us that the safari guides said they were seeing more elephants here than Minneriya NP. Reading online it appears that the elephants mi e along corridors between parks. We reached the first group and counted about 60, including some babies. Also spotted some beautiful birds! Moved along and another group came in to view! A similar number and we got closer!  Wonderful afternoon, leaving the park at 6pm with so many photographs!

I was so disappointed. Since it's a national park, i expected that they would care more for the animals and have a maximum for have many jeeps they allow to drive in. There was a lot of elephants, but even more jeeps. The jeeps sorrounded the elephants, keeping them caught in the middle of loud tourists and cars that never turned off the engine. They looked scared, horrified. Some were even separated by the jeeps and was left outside away from their herd. Most of the way we had to wait in line with probably more than fifty other jeeps to get further. I can't understand how this place is so highly recommended, and am so dissapointed in myself for falling for it. I truly regret it, and hope I can change others opinion. Skip it! The park isn't that beautiful either. It was just very expensive and dissapointing. Take a trip on Sigiriya rock instead. That's beautiful.
saw around 200 elephants in their habitat in this park. highly recommand if you are like to see wild elephants

We were delighted to get up close to a herd,of,over seventy elephants and see a wide range of birds on our safari. However, be aware that the roads are horrendous and the journey to and from the wildlife is an ordeal particularly for anyone with a bad back.

We had a fabulous guide who pointed out many different birds and stopped numerous times to let us take pictured and also very informative. The highlight was a herd of 100+ elephants which we watched with fascination. There were a few bull elephants and some very young calves. Great afternoon and first visit to a wild life park.

There was a herd of about 80 elephants (only about 5% of SriLankan elephants have tusks) at the lake, with about 120 head of cattle grazing next to them but what was the most amazing sight was the 100 odd safari vehicles lined up in a straight line watching the elephant. The roads in the park are attrocious but there are other animals such as water buffalo, and peacocks abound showing off their plumage.

We hadn‚Äôt planned this trip but when talking to fellow guests at our hotel we were tempted to go, we were not disappointed. Organised by the hotel we left at 1.30 and were back by 5.30, in that time we saw a great many elephants, are driver also pointed out various birds, monkeys and even a huge bees nest. We took a good many photos as well as videos, the drivers are not allowed to go closer than 200 meters, but if you have a good camera you would get some stunning shots.
Really worth visiting to watch herds of Elephants up close ....but before visit check with the locals regarding the movements of Elephants...into various nearby national parks...

We visited the park with a local safari company 'kalum jeep safari hababara' He timed our visit so we got to see a huge group of elephants close to before other trucks heard about them. The park is full of wildlife.  Lots of birds, gekos, even spotted an alligator. Roads are bumpy as you'd expect. Great place to see elephants.
This park is good for elephant lovers. Can see large herds of elephants there. Some rare birds species can be seen here too. Safari time starts after 2.30 p.m
Amazing trip here by jeep.  We saw hundreds of elephants that were close enough to really enjoy.  Definitely worth coming.
Brilliant afternoon. Elephants in abundance as well as birds, monkeys, crocodiles, Jackals to name a few. We had a truly magical trip and to see the babies was a utter joy.
Many elephants to see mainly around the lake area.  The number of bird species was well worth investing in some binoculars.
Kaudulla national park is the best place to witness large no of wild elephants. You need to have a 4 wheel drive if not you can hire one in  Habarana. Must visit place for wild life lovers.

Went in to the park despite misgivings about numbers of people in jeeps in a massive queue. Enjoyed it overall, saw 100+ elephants in our late afternoon trip starting about 15:00. That's your reason to go, right there. Didn't see that much else, but there are some good birds there, even for the casual twitcher (big eagles, brightly coloured bee-eaters, etc). Downside? Absolutely wacky races. I jest not, at one point we saw 60+ elephants in a group, and there were 30+ jeeps in a group watching them, jostling for position. The good news is that the wildlife ignored us completely, but it feels "odd" to me. The only safari I've done before was in Tanzania which was empty of other vehicles. All the drivers want their clients to have the best photo (= bigger tip for them), which doesn't help. If you can ignore this, it's good fun. The tracks were hard and massively bumpy, so expect to get thrown around a lot and pick up a few bruises - all part of the experience, (unless you're frail!)
Lovely to see so many elephants in the wild , enjoying "family" getogethers by the lake.  Baby elephants running round playing and making a nuisnce of themselves with the adults

it was my first time on a jeep safari to wildlife park, the area is huge!Great experience to embrace the nature. Not a wide variety of animals to spot though, main highlight is the big herd of elephants. If you're a big fan of these jungle jumbo, this is the place for you.
A great place to see elephants but lot of vehicles. Lots of bird life and small mammals. Big area so you can get away from the majority of other vehicles. Beware of charging elephants!!!

I can not understand how anyone could book a trip to Sri Lanka and then one day go on an elephant safari to see these majestic creatures in the wild and then the next day go and sit in a basket on their back and ride around on them while their handler hits them with a hook. Elephants belong in the wild and it is wonderful to go to Kaudulla and see them there. Unlike Yalla or Udawalawe, the elephants here are free to roam from one National park to another. It's truly wonderful to see so many happy elephants grazing and bathing and playing. When we went there were less jeeps as well than the 300 odd that go to Udawalawe at any time and they respect the animals and don't get too close which made me happy. We had a great experience.

We had a very good safari in Kaudulla National Park. Saw nearly 100 odd elephants in 5 groups. This looks like a sure shot place to see these majestic creatures in their habitat. Worth a visit if you have time.
We had a great trip organised locally. The elephant were plentiful, but the highlight was the birds on show! Good local driver with amazing vision!

I was going to go to the Minneriya park but I was told by a few travellers it's so crowded all you see is hundreds of jeeps surrounding the elephants so I asked around and found a one man safari operation from polonnaruwa who takes you to the less popular Kaudulla National Park which also worked out cheaper plus I was lucky I had the jeep all to myself yes he even goes with just one person no extra charge however you have to pay for entrance fee per person at the gates but I had a great time 100s of elephants all around a large lake I took the afternoon safari which the guide advised me to take
That was amazing place. You can see one time like 69 to 70 elephants.that was great experience I ever had ..!!

I liked that the elephants were in their natural habitat and free to do their own thing, and we were able to get fairly close to them without disturbing them.. I didn't like that we were one of hundreds of jeeps driving all over the place with people just their to take selfies with the elephants in the background...we were lucky enough to have a great guide who actually took us a different way and off the beaten track to really enjoy observing the elephants ....

We visited in mid January 2018. We deliberated long and hard about whether we should go as, although we love to see wildlife (especially elephants) we didn't want to contribute to the animals' disturbance or anxiety as other reviewers suggested can happen. We didn't want to be in a large convoy of jeeps either. In the end we thought we'd give it a go. The jeep safari was arranged by our accommodation host who hired us a jeep and driver for just the 2 of us. On arrival a guide joined us that we hadn't ordered but we went with it anyway. He said he was a volunteer but I doubt that. To be fair the park guide (who joined us in the back of the jeep) was well informed and pointed out stuff that we probably wouldn't have seen on our own - he "controlled" the driver, telling him when to stop. We set off at about 1pm and for the first couple of hours didn't see anyone else as we drove the tracks spotting various birds, a couple of crocs, a turtle, land monitor and thoroughly enjoyed the drive. Occasionally we came across a lone elephant which was nice. The guide seemed to be very apologetic that we hadn't found hundreds of elephants. There is a definite sense that they think the size of their tip is commensurate with the number of elephants spotted. This is a real problem. Later in the afternoon jeeps seemed to gather together and then it happened - a group of about 30 elephants emerged. This caused a frenzy as EVERYONE raced towards them and then jostled for position effectively corralling them on the patch of grass they were eating. The jeeps virtually encircled them and whilst the elephants didn't seem too concerned, it was an unnecessary encroachment. This behaviour would not be allowed in Etosha National Park in Namibia or Chobe in Botswana where we saw lots of elephants but at a safe and unintrusive distance. When elephants are spotted there is no control at all: no minimum distance, no path to keep to, just a free for all. Not good. They must do something to sort this out or eventually it will ruin everything. Sadly, I think someone will have to be killed or seriously injured before they do anything about it. We enjoyed the day, loved the scenery, saw lots, and gave a generous tip. Our low score reflects our displeasure at the lack of controls in terms of visitor numbers and behaviour, and lack of respect for the elephants. Hopefully, if we all score it lower because of this, they eventually may do something to protect the treasures that they have in this park.
It was a great experience to see lots of wild elephants at the same time. We really enjoyed our time. Safari was amazing. On our way we saw lots of wild animals. Such an amazing place to visit.

Very nice experience with elephants. It is not easy to drive the trail. The drivers are very professional. The park guards are very attentive and their  eyes are like radars. They can see and differentiate different animals in park. A little disappointed as we could only see elephants walking and bathing.  Few birds and some monkeys. I recommend to chose other National Parks towards south east of the island.

We went with Kalum jeep safari (https://www.tripadvisor.se/Attraction_Review-g665220-d11621680-Reviews-Kalum_Jeep_Safari-Habarana_North_Central_Province.html) and had the time of our lives! We ended up all alone with 90 elephants, all alone! We also saw deers, monkeys, snake,  chameleons, alligators, birds etc. The road is very bumpy so wear a sports bra!

The park is beautiful, however the experience was tainted by the swarm of 40 jeeps rushing all at once to get a place to view the elephants. On multiple occasions the bigger elephants tried to warn off tourist jeeps ahead of us - it was a disturbing sight to see as the elephants were clearly stressed. I would definitely not recommend this experience to other people until they put regulations in place to protect the animals from stress.

We went to Kaudulla as road to alternative was blocked by a traffic accident, but this was probably better than the alternative. The jeep ride was bumpy and exciting, particularly when we forded the river to see even more elephants. We saw a lizard, lots of different birds, then a lone elephant striding out, followed by a group of 25-30 grazing by the lakeside, which we stayed and watched for some time. The whole experience was excellent.

Just loved our afternoon Safari in this beautiful National Park, it was so much fun! So many elephants to be seen around the tank, some coming up close to our truck. We were also able to see wild buffalo, lemurs and peacocks and a stunning sunset on the way back. The park was also not as busy with safari trucks, unlike Yala, so we were able to see so many more and spend more time watching them.  Awesome experience and a highlight of our trip.
This was a really great experience! I love elephants and with this safari I was able to see a lot of them and had a lot of fun with the driver!
We visited early December 2018, seen more than 100 elephants some with tusks. Nice surrounding, safari takes unto 4 hrs, possibility to see other animals. Be aware with Safari tuck mafia
Huge herd of elephants by the lake. Spent most of the time watching them.   A couple of other animals as we drove around.   Elephants main show!

Visited this park by Jeep and saw about 200 elephants in various herds. They ranged from very small to large and just gently grazed on the vast grassland. Some of the younger elephants were playful and ran through the shallow water at the edge of the lake. Absolute highlight of our trip to Sri Lanka!

The jeep was not very comfortable but we had wonderful elephant sightings. We saw at least 150! They ranged from very small to the matriarchs and large bulls. We were on a rich grassland that becomes a huge lake during the monsoon. The elephants were in different herds and some walked down in front of us to swim in the lake. also great birdlife. A great outing
You can see herds of wild Elephants very close. Numbers can be as large as 100. It include tuskers, large bulls and small ones.

There are large herds of elephants and almost as large herds of jeeps in this park! I was impressed and moved by the tolerance and patience of these animals with us humans and the visit rather raised the questions in us: What are we tourist doing???
we were lucky to see a huge amount of elephants plus baby elephants. The jeep tours are awesome experience.
Large herd of elephants roaming and playing. Felt the jeeps kept a respectable distance away from them while still trying to get the best view for the passengers. A great experience.

We went with my two sons and the driver was Mr Mahinda who was a very experienced driver and safari jeep owner.  We saw about 70 to 80 elephants at the park at the close range.  Park was very beautiful wildlife watching. Not only elephants eaglea, eagls neat, peacocks and many more birds can be seen at the park. Mr. Mahinda was a very experienced very careful helpful and who loves wildlige.  He showed lot of birds and their nest which was very beautiful.  His jeep number is 07(Habarana Safari Jeep Association)

Definitely a must do when in Srilanka. We went to two national parks and enjoyed this one more. The elephants are majestic animals and its a pleasure to see them in the wild. We saw 3 herds of over 50 elephants each. It got really exciting when we came across a bull elephant who looked like he was going to charge us. Thankfully our driver and guide managed it well.

If you love elephants - this park is just the thing. Herds of elephants, grazing, bathing, playfully fighting young ones, mums feeding little ones - it is a sight which I will never tire of. We even saw a female elephant dragging its still born calf along. She was protected by a few larger elephants but even as they went about their business of pulling out the grass and chomping away they never forgot the little lifeless thing at their feet - very sad actually!The herds in the Minneriya Park have moved into this one and is highly recommended. It is also for me a nicer park. There are several birds with looking out for and of course the crocs in the river. Well worth a visit. But please take care you don't intrude on the animals. Its their home.
We took a jeep from our hotel to the park. Loads of elephants, playing, feeding and even mourning the loss of a pregnancy (mom carried the foetus) we watch for hours

Safari in Kaudulla NP in december was a total disappointment. We have seen many elephants, maybe like 150 or so, gathered around the tank. But on the other side, jeeps were just way tooo many, packed with people. They were keep coming and racing for the spots, making an incredibble noise and emitting a lots of gas. It was sad to see the swarm of people focusing on small herds of elephants. The National Park should, in my opinion, control the access to the park somehow. For example only full jeeps could be allowed. We've seen many cars with just 2 people. The park is beautiful, there a lots of elephants and wild buffalos, but the agitation of the jeeps just ruins the whole atmosphere. Not to mention that it is not a cheap experience.

We took an early morning safari to see wild life and were rewarded with  sighting lots of Elephants, beautiful birds, cattle and peacocks.  It had  rained all  night so the park was very muddy and the dirt roads a challenge to drive on.  Couple of jeeps did get stuck in the mud and had to be pulled out!  Ours became quite muddy when the driver tried to pull us out of a rut as well.  The lake was beautiful and enjoyed the fresh air and animals in the wild.  The trip however was extremely pricey considering it was Sri Lanka and the locals pay almost 20% of what we as foreigners did.

We found a guy to take us at a company advertising on the road in habarana, for 3 of us it cost 4300 lkr each total including park fee. We didn't tip as he over charged us so assumed he was pocketing the extra 300 each. It was good that the elephants were at this park as it is cheaper than Minneriya. We visited at 2:30pm. There were plenty of elephants, we saw about 150 in 4 separate groups. We got nice and close and managed to get an exciting chase from the leader elephant. Our driver was very good and often took the lead. There wasn't much else to see apart from elephants. The only shock was the crappy vehicles they use. Most of them are 2wd which is surprising considering the park is driving through muddy grassland lands. We spent 30mins trying to winch out a guy who got stuck in the mud, he had a 2wd and his tyres were almost bald so it wasnt surprising he was stuck. In the end 3 of us had to push him out. Try to find or ask for a 4wd vehicle or a good driver as if you want to get close to the elephants you will need it.

Saw approx 200 elephants on the day! All ages and sizes from tiny baby 1 month old! Got very up close within a few metres, less than 10m. Plus owl, peacock, monkey.  Cost 5200rupee entrance, plus 4000rupee for the jeep plus tip - you can get driver cheaper than this even as low as 2000 we found out after the fact! But if you like elephants this place was lazy with them on the day we went. Awesome experience, very happy.
Took a jeep safari (a number to choose from) into this Park and got close to a couple of very large herds of Indian elephants.  Excellent experience, highly recommended.

There are numerous jeep-safari-firms that offer trips into the Kaudulla National Park.  You might want to do some comparing, but my impression is that it's mostly "same-same".  We went on a 3 hour safari, and that's plenty.  A short trip before we enter the park, and then again about 20-30 minutes of drive into the park while watching diferent birds and other animals you might happen to see.  Suddenly the trees are gone, and you see this huge open area.  This is were you very often get to see a lot of elephants.  You get up and close - we were as close as 3-5 meters with our jeep!  Amazing. During rainy season they move to a different park.  Be sure to do a quick checking around before you decide which park you go to to optimalize your chances of getting a "up and close" encounter with these enormous animals.
Viewing of elephants with babies.also saw a Tusker with huge tusks. Saw different birds in the water.the driver of the Jeep was knowledgeable

A wonderful ride in a open roof jeep. Herds of Sri Lankan elephants which is an impressive sight. A wonderful experience and with a good driver/guide you see a lot more. We saw large owls, eagles, two types of squirrels, monkeys and many more animals. On a nice and sunny day don‚Äôt forget water and sunscreen. Go enjoy, worth it.
If you want to see wild elephants then this is the place to go. Not much else there but seeing 200 wild elephants wandering about was just amazing!

Yes, you will see elephants by the boatload most of the time, however spending more than two hours (which was the length of my jeep tour) was really not enough to drive along a 15-mile stretch of pot-holed dirt road thru jungle and then scrubby grasslands. Did see a few monkeys and even a crocodile in the river, but I suspect there is much more to view than what I had the opportunity to see. Worth a one time visit, but wouldn't make a second.

What an experience!! Great fun in the jeep to get to elephants. The track was so muddy and we were stuck a couple of times. However the drivers all help each other out and it added to the fun.  So many elephants to view but I am not sure who was watching who? There were about 30 jeeps all lined up watching the elephants. Keep your eyes peeled throughout the whole journey as we saw a lone male elephant peeking out of the trees which was the best experience of all as it was right next to the jeep.  We paid 4000 rupees for the jeep and 5700 rupees to get into the park (2 people). Well worth it.

What an amazing day! The anticipation of seeing wild elephants was high and the tour did not disappoint!! Spectacular! First there were a few as we came into the wildlife reserve in our awesome jeep, and then we saw more and more. We were taken away by these majestic creatures! The surroundings were beautiful and so peaceful. It was hard to forget that these were wild animals. Our driver was skilled and knew the best spots whilst being very respectful of these gorgeous animals!! Unforgettable experience!!

Had a 3 hour tour arranged by habarana cinnamon hotel - had a close up view of 150 elephants without imposing on them. Also saw many birds including sea eagles really close. Our driver and guide were knowledgeable and informative. - able to spot and name many birds in trees and on the ground that we would have missed Worth paying extra for the 3 hour tour - you get to see an amazing amount of widlife You should take binoculars and a hat  - and be prepared for a few hair-raising moments in the truck !
We saw at least 30 wild elephants with young too. An amazing sight. Also deer, buffalo, foxes and lots of different types of birds. Would recommend.
Went to a safari to this park. was worth it as we saw a huge herd of elephants & of course interesting birds. In case you are around this area this is a must.
Great safari trip, organized through Mutu Village with very experienced driver. We had lots of fun and saw many elephants, birds and other animals

From the first lone bull elephant semi seen through the forest to the hundreds in different groupings this was the place to see elephants. At play and group interaction made for a fascination few hours. Don't forget the herds of buffalo and other animals that can be seen if you are lucky like small spotted deer. Bird life also abound so make sure your driver is the slowest and you will see more.

Thanks to advice from our amazing driver, we headed to Kaudulla instead of Minneriya NP in hopes of seeing some elephants in their natural habitat. We were advised to go in the afternoon and were NOT let down! Seeing all of these elephants along with water buffalo and tons of beautiful birds was probably the highlight of our trip.

If you are already around Sigiriya, Dambulla or Habarana better to do a good safari in Kaudulla national park.  In close proximity to Habarana there are three parks namely Minneriya, Kaudulla and Eco park. Elephant herds move around these three parks depending upon the weather conditions.  Before starting the Safari please check with the jeep safari provider about the park to be visited. They know the movements of the elephants as they operate in all three parks. You are not allowed to get down from the vehicle until you get out from the park due to safety. If you are lucky you have the chance to more than 100 elephants in an hours time

Kaudulla National Park is about 30-45 minutes by road from Habarana, most of the drive is on the road to Trinco, and takes you past Galoya Station. Do ask around at Habarana which of the nearby national parks will provide the best opportunity to see elephants. One requires a jeep to travel in the parks. We were lucky to stumble upon Amal who works from Hotel Prasanna, a modest hotel/restaurant located pretty close to the exit to Habarana Lodge/Village. Amal was very patient, pleasant, speaks excellent English and German, and very knowledgeable about the park and Sri Lanka in general. He pointed out plenty of wildlife including monkeys, birds, squirrels, and even a hornet's nest on our way and in the park, which we otherwise would have missed. While "The Gathering" had about 200 elephants and prolly 30 jeep loads of tourists, thankfully there is plenty of space and all what the jeeps need to do is park near this large herd(s) and do not have to chase the elephants. So didn't feel the jeeps took away any from the experience. The elephants themselves were supremely oblivious to the parked jeeps. We did see a smaller herd separate of The Gathering. The Gathering is a must see when in Sri Lanka. Believe the best time is during the dry season, July to October. Ask around for jeep rates. We paid 3500 LKR for the jeep from Habarana and paid the park fees by ourselves at the entrance. Best to start early afternoon on a week day for more time and less crowds.

Jeep safari ride with lots of elephants, birds, monkeys, alligator.  We arrived late in the afternoon and went in the evening.   We had to leave early due to torrential rains.  There was a lake in between the forest animals in their natural habitat.  The tuskers baby elephants and their mothers are a sight to watch.  The lone elephant can charge at your jeep so you need to be careful

This safari was the best - a great way to experience elephants truly in their wild habitat yet feel as if you are quite close.  The guides were very good and attentive to ensuring the visitor had the best experience possible.  Great photography and huge numbers of elephants, baby elephants, bird life and just watching nature ...entranced!

We hired a driver who collected us from Colombo airport and drove us around the cultural triangle for 6 days. He also pre booked a local jeep driver who collected us from our hotel, cinnamon lodge Habarana, for 4000 rupee  (¬£20) not bad for two me n wife. Our driver Jaya also came along, which was handy a he could translate and inform the jeep driver any requests we had. There's 3 local national parks that the heards of elephants roam freely between, so it's handy having a driver who knows where the main heards are on any particular day. Entry into the park was around 3000 rupee  (¬£15) each, I paid at the entrance for two n jeep. The experience was magical, dozens of elephants with calfs roaming around close up to us. There must have been around 30 jeeps in the park that evening. When it was time to leave, all the jeep drivers jocky for positions as it's only single file once you move out of the open, plenty of fun getting back splashing through water covered dirt track roads, we had an advantage, as our jeep was 4 wheel drive, most of the others were not.

We visited and saw approx 100 wild elephants congregating at a water source which was an amazing site. One downside was the amount of jeeps on safari which slightly spoilt the mood and unfortunately probably affected the elephants.

We were advised by the local hotel to visit this national park as elephants had been spotted there on previous day. Also, we didn't have any choice but to select the morning slot. We reached at the ticket gate by 5.30. As it was not a full tourist season, there were only two more vehicles apart from ours. We were fortunate to see lots of elephants. Fighting of two youngs were the highlights. Apart from elephants, spotted deers, painted storkes, pelicans, bee eaters, fish owl, ..... were also spotted. We were more than satisfied with the sightings.
Amazing for a jeep safari, saw so many wild elephants , crocodile, storks, lizards, deer, monkeys. Enjoyed it immensely.

This is a true nature. Very beautiful. Park with around 250 elephants and some other species (eagles etc.). We arrived in the late afternoon and stayed untill sunset. Perfect time. Prepare your cameras !
Watch these majestic wild elephants in their natural habitat. Its thrilling being so close, but not too close or they will charge the Jeep!

It's in the Trincomalee road. Past the habarana city it's about a half hours drive in to the park gate. We saw a gathering of about 300 elephant. Its not something we see every day.there are only elephant and no other animal at all which is a downer.all types elephants are there in the  herd.small babies, tuskers, and nursing mother's are among them. If youre a big elephant fan it's a must visit destination.

Really enjoyed this safari and managed to see elephants close up - there were over 200!  A couple of the elephants charged at the numerous jeeps when they got too close, but the jeep guides seemed able to anticipate this and made a quick getaway! We also saw a hornets nest, monkeys, a giant squirrel, crocodile, eagle, so the trip very worthwhile to see the animals in their natural environment.

Do not miss this natural wonder! Large herds of wild elephants and water buffaloes with an astounding variety of birds. So lovely. A very experience for the family especially children. So amazing so peaceful so educational. Worth every cent for the jeep safari. A must see place.

We were taken with an amazing guide, who was deaf, but he was amazing at spotting things. I know BSL so between us we had a fantastic day and I would recommend it to anyone - word of warning, the day we went (out of season) there was 300 vehicles, but our driver and guide made sure we didnt spend much time with them, as the reserve is massive. Best day of our holiday!

We took a trip to this safari park from habarna which was very easy to arrange and cost around 6000 rupees for two, plus 5000 rupees park entry fee. The park was quiet when we entered and gradually got busier later in the afternoon with around 10 safari vehicles at the busiest time. The park is great for seeing herds of elephant, of all ages from baby elephant to larger fully grown. A wonderful experience, and worth every penny. We happened to see a single elephant in the water, washing itself and spraying water around, at a time there were no other vehicles around - fantastic
This park is good to watch elephants. Best time is August to November where you can see large elephants gathering. Good to see birds as well and other big mammals can not have easier sifting.

This was a great jeep trip. We saw peacocks monkeys and many elephants. they were bathing in a river and we were able to watch them for a long time from the back of the jeep. This is a great activity, for all ages.

This was my second visit to Kaudulla in 6 months. I wasn't disappointed on both occasions with plentiful late afternoon sightings of grazing elephants (including many babies) on the menu. You can usually get quite near the elephants but take binoculars along if you're interested in observing the animals more closely. Reserve about 2 hours for a reasonably good visit to the different clusters and grazing areas.
Beautiful elephants, beautiful scenery. Pick a vehicle with forward facing seats.  Some vehicles had clear windscreen, which would be better than looking at black canvas.
We went to kaudulla early morning around six o'clock. Saw some elephant, eagle and the nest, peacocks. It was an excellent place to see elephants on October Month

We wanted to go the Mineryia park but our host told us that no elephant were there at this time but we're in Kaudulla. We went to the Kaudulla national park with a guide that our host recommended us. We paid 9500LKR for 2 people. We stayed 2h in the park, the guide was kind with us, he let us the time we needed to take photos of the hundred elephants standing there. Such a beautiful place with birds, monkeys and elephants!

A place to be if you want to see wild elephants.. Lots of wild elephants!   I never saw big herds like that before.. The only downside is the many jeeps on diesel.. It would be better if they invest in hybrid transportation..

The safari here is all about elephants although we saw some birds and a couple of small crocs.  But you get up really close to the elephants and can see them in their natural habitat. It is worth bargaining for the cost of your safari by approaching the several shops near the entrance to the Cinammon Lodge hotel in Habarana as all the companies do the same route basically.  The Cinammon Lodge (a fabulous place to stay and even more fabulous to eat in) charges US$70 per person which is double or more than you can bargain for - at least when it is not peak season.

We did an afternoon safari and were really lucky to see 300 elephants being very much fun to watch. We also saw over 40 different types of bird including 5 different bird of prey. Guide was brilliant .
If you love elephants this is the place to be. We stayed for two hours just watching the 200 elephants that were out on that day. This was our favourite experience whilst in Sri Lanka

Wow. Fantastic experience. Gobsmacked Do have a few bruises though from jeep, a very bumpy ride. Lots of Elephants. Dont get nervous as 1 lady did. They protect there young. The jeep drivers no what there doing.

If you find yourself in central Sri Lanka and love elephants, then Kaudulla is where you must go. Unlike Yala you won't see a huge variety of animals here (we did see se crocodiles, lizards, and birds) but you come for the elephants. Vast open plains with elephants for as far as the eye can see. Not totally overcrowded with jeeps so it's possible to get closer to these fantastic beasts.
We went to this park with Akila Village and Lake Adventure.  It was a good attraction.  We did see a lot of wildlife including deer, peacocks, water buffalo, and elephants.

If you time it right you can see the gathering of 60 to 70 elephants.  In august we saw new borns and males with full tusks "Tuskers". Go with a tour company who will take you to where the elephants are on the particular day as they move around.  Try to get a jeep with forward facing seats rather than side facing... better ride.  Also make sure your jeep is 4 wheel drive...  yes there is such a thing as 2 wheel drive jeeps and they got stuck in the river crossings.  This is definitely a bucket list item.

We went on safari at the start of September with Compass Safari. They were excellent, with the trip of 3-4 hours costing us just 1000lkr each, leaving from Habarana. During the trip we were able to see several herds of elephants, the biggest of which was around 40-50 out in the open. It was really special being able to get up an close to them, although as other reviewers have pointed out, there were a lot of other jeeps around at the same time. There wasn't much else to see in the park, but we did spot an eagle on our way back out, and the landscape was very beautiful. My main tip would be to have a check of the reviews for Kaudulla and Menneriya the day of/before your trip and ensure that people have been reporting sightings before you travel. Most companies seem flexible and will take you wherever you ask. I would definitely book directly rather than through a hotel as this will save you a lot of money (we did ours for $10 each including tips, plus a small bus fare to Habarana, while the hotel charged $30 each). Anyone with residence visas: They will honour these and allow entry at the local rate.

We were booked to go to Minneriya however the elephants had moved so we came to this park.  What can one say about seeing a herd of over 150 elephants.  The drivers are well trained and respectful of others. With respect for each other they made sure each driver managed to have his clients so the elephants up close. They also were respectful of the elephants. A wonderful experience.

This afternoon safari was totally amazing and well worth it. 3.5 hours inside the park and as we drove along through the jungle we were not sure what to expect. Then we came out of the trees and headed to the lake and there were 10s of elephants all feeding in the grass. It was a very very enjoyable time. There must have been close to 100 elephants wondering around and it was beautiful watching them together. One of the best days we have had. Yes the park is busy, we were jeep 99 but plenty of room for all and we didn't feel like we couldn't get a good view. Really recommend

If you can ignore all the vehicles and people this is worth a visit just to see the big herds of wild Elephants. We just drove to Habarana and picked up two small game vehicles on the road @ R6000 each vehicle. (Half the price the hotel was going to charge us.) We enjoyed seeing the youngsters play and males trying their luck! We were lucky enough to see a few on the streets near the park navigating their way around cars and villages.

I came to Sri Lanka to experience the ellie "GATHERING" in Minneriya National Park.  It did not happen this year because of plenty of water.  BUT....the ellies did come to this park at Kaudulla.  So my second day I spent here instead of Minneriya.  Had some GREAT ellie viewing and pictures.  The number of jeeps/vans/ etc.  was somewhat overwhelming with some guests having NO clue how to act around animals and some drivers who obviously don't give a damn about the animals and rev their engines and jockey for position.  But the ellies appear to be somewhat used to it and provided some fine opportunities to witness their behaviors and actions.  I really enjoyed my time in this park.

I am torn about what to review this park.  I knew before that this was one of the 'popular' parks, but apparently much less busy that Yala (which I do not see how it is possible that Yala be busier than KAdulla was when we went).  We went at about 3pm which is when the elephants start gathering near the water.  We were one of the first jeeps to get there, racing across the park.  However, as we approached the elephants, we could see more and more jeeps approaching from every direction. It was amazing to see the elephants, we were so close to them, but I am not sure how much I fully enjoyed it because of the amount of jeeps.  I counted about 80 jeeps and as many elephants.  We then passed even more jeeps as we left the park. Some jeeps also got very close to the elephants, and other jeeps were blocking the elephants path, which meant the elephants were unable to reach their family on the other side.  some of the elephants were very clearly distressed by being separated by a line of jeeps. I recognise that having the elephants in a national park and being watched by jeeps at least means they are safer from poachers, but it was still a bit difficult to see.  However, if you are desperate to see elephants, you will not be disappointed. I recommend asking a local guide before hand whether to visit Minnerya or Kadulla because the elephants move back and forth between the two - you do not want to go to the wrong one!

Took an afternoon safari for about 2 hours in Kaudulla National Park and saw over 100 elephants. The elephants we saw were several herds that crowded together throughout the park. The safari trucks stuck to the trails and the only close encounters we had with the elephants were when they would cross the trails on their own accord. Most of the elephants we saw were a bit far away but were astonishing. The herds had many baby elephants and we got to watch them playing and bathing in the mud. Also saw water buffalo and crocodiles in the river on the way into the park.

This experience should not be missed, but does have two sides to it. The touristic part - quite expensive at 12000 LKR for a private safari with pickup. Where "private" means alone in a jeep, but you will be surrounded by 99 others. Its a bumpy 30 minute ride to the main plain filled with exhaust fumes and sweaty tourists. Obviously, these are the downsides. If you can shield out the chaos, you will be rewarded with the amazing part: We saw about 250 elephants trek from the jungle down to the waters between 4-6pm. It was absolutely majestic and filled me with a sense of calm as these giant animals made their way slowly through the grass while grazing. You will see Elephants of all sizes including babies. We also enjoyed their banter and playful wrestling between the adolescents. There are also moments of excitement when large males seem to disagree with the amount of vehicles that surround them and start walking towards jeeps. Luckily all drivers put safety first and made way for the animals. Besides elephants there's not too much else to see in terms of wildlife. We saw a massive beehive and 4 peacocks, but don't expect much more. All in all I would recommend this safari to others and return again myself! If you are doing this from Polonnaruwa, expect a 1 hour drive to the entrance of the park.

We took a safari from Habarana organised from our B&B. There were 4 of us and the price was LKR4000 per person, which included the entrance fee to the park. We didn't choose this park specifically, but this was where the elephants were currently hanging out so... The guide, driver and vehicle were all great. The guide knew lots of information, and stopped to point out various animals as we trundled through the overgrown forest area on our way to the tank. Sadly we didn't see any sloth bears- wrong time of day. The park is beautiful, and we were lucky enough to witness The Gathering, where over 200 elephants gather at one time. Some of the baby elephants we saw were only 3 months old. All of this was great. The only negatives were the quantity of tourist jeeps in the park at the same time- there must have been 20+ in there and more coming all the time. Most of them had only 2 people in 4-6 person jeeps, and no effort had been made to reduce the number of jeeps by combining tour groups. Obviously they were all looking for elephants, so the jeeps were all zooming around the same bit of park, making it noisy and congested. It seems there are no established tracks, and the jeeps can drive wherever they want. The second negative was, when they found elephants many would drive straight into the middle of a group, so close you could almost lean out and touch them. The jeeps would often leave there engines on, and would all bunch up together with no clear exit strategy should the elephants become agitated and charge, which we saw them do on at least 4 occasions that afternoon. Not only did this seem really cruel and intrusive to these groups of elephants, many of whom had young with them, but it was incredibly dangerous! When an elephant charges at a group of jeeps it it pretty terrifying! We were very firm with our guide, requesting to stay a good distance from the animals and to calmly watch them, explaining that if they wanted to come near us then fine, but we didn't want to invade their space, however given the antics of the other drivers I'm amazed that there has not been a serious accident yet. I have never been on safari in Africa, but I'm pretty sure this sort of behaviour would not be tolerated. So, in summary, the park was beautiful, the elephants a delight, and the humans were reckless, insensitive and dangerous. Not much of a surprise really.

Apparently depending on rainfall the elephants move between parks, we were advised to visit Kaudulla to find the elephants. We saw the odd one, pretty close as well, so were pleased then we saw more elephants than we could have imagined. Watching  then in their own environment was great. The attention was drawn to the baby that was hiding behind its mums legs, great sights and not to be missed. I understand afternoon is the best time for the trip.

I can't express my words, It was an amazing experience you must take during your lifetime. I have never seen so much of elephants in one place. I think we sawaround 500 elephants or more. (some elephants migrated from Minneriya forest during the time of our visit) We had a really nice time. There were baby elephants as well. And i think there were some big elephants who is acting like a leader for small groups, they make sure jeeps don't hurt them. Be mindful elephants may attack some jeeps. We witness an event like that. But not our jeep. Drivers were very quick and they know how to face those situations. So don't worry.  If you are afraid of elephants do not go. As long as you don't shout and make noises and do not hurt them, they don't trouble you. For all who wish to have a good wildlife experience i highly recommend you to go there. Plenty of safari services available in and around the area. If you're around Habarana or Giritale area or going to Polonnaruwa better visit Kaudulla Forest as well. Safari time around 2.30-3 hours.

A friend recommended a jeep operator and I booked the safari with him the day before. We met the jeep and arrived at the park around 3 pm on a Friday. The driver took us to a place where there were over 200 elephants and only  2 other jeeps. We spend about 90 minutes watching elephants and it was an unforgettable trip.

Incredible national park to witness Sri Lankan wild elephants. It is also said to be the home for around 25 species of mammals and over 150 species of birds. Plenty of safari services available in and around the area to browse through the park as well. A highly recommended tour if you're around Habarana or Giritale area.

We went just after lunch, before the majority of tourists got there, and we were so lucky to see a few hearts join together at the watering hole. There must have been about a hundred elephants, some of them little babies. We even had a stare-down with a mama who was protecting her three-week old, who was wobbly and adorable. It's a great park, one of the best in the country, and while there reneger any promises with wildlife safaris, this is as close as you can get.

Visited on our first day day in Sri Lanka and what an experience! We were only expecting to see a few elephants but were extremely lucky and ended up seeing over 300 elephants!! I think the tour does depend on the guide you have - our guide spoke great English so acted as both guide and driver. He really respected the animals, turning off the engine and never getting too close, and was extremely  knowledgable about the elephants too. Although there were quite a few jeeps around we felt this didn't hamper our experience as the elephants still wander around doing their own thing. Overall, an incredible wildlife experience!

This was a cool trip, we saw about 40 elephants which was a great experience. Elephants are the main highlight of the trip and there are not many other animals to see, unless you are into birds! I'd recommend though, especially to see the 2 week old elephant.
