We went a day after heavy rain so our driver said the elephants numbers were down as a result compared to the previous day. We still saw at least 50 elephants in different groups, including some very young ones. The park is beautiful. We were able to watch the elephants for as long as we wanted. Our driver was very considerate of the animals and did not get too close. The only negative was the sheer number of other safari vehicles, each wanting to get close to the animals, which was a little overwhelming at times.

There was a huge line of jeeps when we got there. We walked to the ticket office which was half a km long of drivers waiting to buy passes and 1 person at the counter servicing everyone. The park and elephants are Beautiful but we were keep no. 200 for the day so there is a lot of people. Some jeeps can also get quite intrusive to the elephants.

An amazing experience! During our time in Habarana we visited this national park as a Jeep safari excursion. We loved the experience and saw in excess of 100+ elephants during the time. It is full of Jeeps and they all try and give their clients the best view of these magnificent creatures. During our time there the elephants didn't seem worried or scared by the Jeeps and other reviews suggest, we may have just been lucky with respectful drivers. Overall an amazing experience.
Our driver knew the park really well. Stunning views and lots of wildlife to see. We were able to see two herds each of approximately 40 elephants which was amazing.

We were driven around by a very friendly guide and were lucky enough to encounter a herd of elephants that were coming for a drink in the park. Very special. The guides in this park respect the animals and their personal space, which is good. Great memories.

We were told all the elephants have moved to this park. We went around 3 pm which was a good time. We got to see elephants going to the lake. Really great experience. Our driver organised the safari jeep, can get one easily in towns.

We have seen lots of elephants gathered around 120s. Some toothed and some with babies. was rainy day, but enjoyed. Ask your diver or guide before safari for elephant gathering whether in minneriya or Kaudulla before starting safari.

We visited Kaudulla National Park on the afternoon of 26 August as part of a 6 person safari jeep tour arranged through our guesthouse. Our safari cost around 4,500 rupees per person (including park fees). When arranging our tour, we were advised that the elephant gathering had moved on from Minneriya National Park (which is also the advice given on the Minneriya website), so a tour to Kaudulla is, at the time of writing, the best way to see wild elephants en masse in this part of Sri Lanka. Our pick up was around 130pm in Polonnaruwa, getting to Kaudulla an hour later and entering the park around 245pm. We left around 5pm. During our visit, we saw maybe in the region of 80 to 100 elephants in different herd sizes scattered throughout the park. The largest group was around 40 to 50 elephants, with many small calves, mothers and younger males. There was an impressive tusked male wandering around as well. Given that this gathering of elephants is so very seasonal, you can obviously expect there to be interest from tourists and locals, so there are always likely to be quite a number of jeeps that follow the trails.  Perhaps some people have a romantic notion of seeing nature in the wild all to themselves, but that's not usually how things work for the price you pay here. If you want exclusivity, you will eventually have to pay a price for that. We did not think the overall experience was as bad as some reviews have portrayed. Most drivers we witnessed appeared to be very respectful and experienced, especially when elephants cross the trails. We did not see any drivers chase the herds off road and they all keep to the tracks, turning engines off when there were elephants nearby and only restarting them when elephants approached closer. The elephants seemed well used to the activity around them and, while that may not seem to be wild nature in the truest sense, the herds and individuals seemed happy enough to wander off in the the opposite direction away from the tracks if they felt the need to do so. Perhaps its a few bad tour drivers that spoil it for others on some days, but given the numbers of elephants moving into the park, there doesn't seem to be any need to chase for a photo opportunity at the moment. It's really a privilege to see these wonderful, beautiful creatures in such great numbers in the wild.  It's a once in a lifetime opportunity for many and a great experience.
There were a lot of elephants and a lot of jeeps as well. I think it was stressful for animals.. We also saw buffalos, some birds and nothing more..

Too many jeeps, with crazy drivers going too close to elephants! Elephants look angry and stressful because of the jeeps. Message to all tourists : please do not shout! Remain silent when you are close to elephants, you are not in a zoo !!! Our driver told us that there are rules in the park, but almost nobody is following them. They have to improve the safaris organization : put a limit of jeeps number, prohibit jeeps which are not following the rules, and ask for full jeeps (it's a pity to see a big jeep with only 2 people inside!) We saw almost only elephants in that park. Jeeps are going straight to elephants area, without taking interest to other animals...

We took a jeep safari to this aprk, as our guide/driver said that not many had been sited at Minneriya, Considering the huge Island & forests, we managed to see them after an hour of driving around. We sited about 40 Elephants going to the lake. The guide said that they have had a dry spell, which you could see by how much the lake had shrunk. a magnificent site to see, when they come up close, amazing. Although others have seen hundreds, it can be hit or miss on the day.

I cannot understand why some people are giving this place poor reviews - yes there's loads of jeeps there but there is no sign of the elephants being upset by the tourists or the jeeps. In fact I would say to all tourists do not go to the so called sanctuaries or orphanages but instead stick to the safaris where you get what you pay for.

Great day out. Cost us in the region of ¬£50pp plus ¬£7.50 tip but we must have seen between 100-120 elephants! If you're not interested in seeing herds of elephants grazing in the national park, you can just drive the road between Habarana and Kaudulla National Park between 1700-1830 and see them as the cross the road out of the park.

Go in the afternoon, prepare for a queue but it is totally worth it! There is a huge herd of elephants who will tolerate the jeeps without much hassle, we saw pregnant elephants, baby elephants and the rest of the herd in August, the jeep drivers do their best to get you very close and I mean very close! I have some wonderful wildlife pictures that I'm so proud of! Worth every penny

We expected to go the Minneriya nat'l park, but our driver told us that the animals moved here, hence the huge line up to enter. I was amazed at the order within what looked like a huge traffic jam and the cooperation between the drivers, manoevering within an inch of each other. We were lucky to have had Indika from Isuru Enterprise (I also have his phone number) as our driver. We told him in advance we were also interested in 'the small stuff', not only elephants, and he came through for us. If you do hire him just make sure he doesn't start driving while you are still taking photos. We did see herds of...jeeps close to the elephants. At the beginning I couldn't get a photo without having another vehicle in the frame, but then it became more orderly and where there was a large convergence of elephants, the Jeeps stood in an orderly line. After that we were also pretty much alone for the rest of the ride. We spent well over two hours in what usually takes about 1.5 hours. In summary: a good adventure.

The elephants are the main attraction in Sri Lanka so obviously wherever they go, the crowds will follow. During our stay the elephants had gathered at Kaudulla so I knew that this park would be popular. However, I wasn't prepared for just how busy it was going to be. We arrived around 2:45pm and the queue of safari jeeps jostling to get in was staggering. Some tried to overtake each other and ended up creating an even bigger mess. This chaotic system needs to be addressed by the park. We finally made it in and headed straight for the are where the elephants can be found. On the way we saw a few birds, an enormous crocodile and some monkeys. When we arrived at the open plain, the sight of the large herd of elephants was amazing. More and more groups began to join and we ended up seeing dozens. The number of jeeps was evident as well and although the jeep we hired added to this, it wasn't the intimate experience I had imagined (But maybe that's my fault for not being realistic). To be fair, there was plenty of space in the park and we were lucky enough to get fairly close to different groups of elephants as they emerged from the forest. It was an unforgettable experience and I suppose the park reaps the benefits in terms of income, so maybe I've been a little bit critical. Seeing elephants cross the main road right in front of us on the way home was pretty cool too!

Kandulla park is very nice area. However, authorities should regulate urgently more strictly  the entrance policy. Indeed, we visited the park with too many safari jeeps at the same time (maybe more than 100 !). All around elefants who are living there. Moreover due to such disorganization, we spent more than one hour in traffic jam created by safari cars waiting for the possibility to buy tickets for entrance. We got the feeling that the priority is more the business related with tickets than the quality of live for the animals. We'll never come back.
Great to see so many elephants in there natural environment. There are alot of jeeps but none drove too close to the elephants when we were there. Kids absolutely loved it.

A wonderful way to experience Asian elephant in a natural environment. Forest, plains and water. The family groups gradually exit from the forest to graze and move to the drinking area. The mix of ages from small babies ,protected by their family group, to older elephants is wonderful. Estimate we saw 130 of which only four displayed any tusks. Probably from a decimated gene pool in the past. At least they should be saved from the poaching common in Africa for ivory to Asia in particular China. The big downside is the apparent total lack of management which allows limitless vehicles to enter the park, to the overall detriment of the elephants, the visitors and safety. It is an accident waiting to happen. Management greed or incompetence? A total lack of supervision destroys the experience as does the failure to educate visitors on behavior.

There were too many vehicles. The animals seemed stressed and tried to move away from cars. It wasn't sustainable tourism. I felt sorry for the animals. A suggested  improvement would be if the park management only allowed for a maximum number of cars each day and offered well trained guides that can tell tourists more about the animals who lives in the park.
A lot of elephants even a baby!! Great experince to see them in their free environment. Other animals also~ Entrance 8.5k R - 4ppl jeep 7.5k R... ask ur guide where is water before select the park

I loved seeing the elephants in their natural environment, but it takes away from the 'natural environment' experience when the number of jeeps seems to exceed the elephants. Perhaps the relevant authorities could do a better job at managing the waves of visitors. Having said that , if you are in the area, this is still a 'do-not-miss' experience.

We had thought we would visit Minneriya on our August trip to SL but we took local advice and visited Kaudulla instead, as most of the elephants had not yet arrived at Minneriya. Saw lots despite a massive thunder storm. Advice is to take a vehicle with large wheels - the jeep we were in was not substantial enough for bad weather and we had to be towed out of the mud 3 times! All added to the adventure though!

Just check the pictures and decide yourself. It was said there are 500 jeeps, estimating 4 persons on it, there comes around 50 humans on each elefant we saw, so its actually more a human gathering then a elefant one. This national park is more to make money then safe wild animals. PS.: we saw the next day at the tank in polonnaruwa wild elefants on the other side of the lake which was much more delightful and for free...!

We visited Kaudulla just a few days ago and it far exceeded my expectations. The park is absolutely beautiful and allowed us to see around 200-300 elephants roaming in the wild. They were walking around extremely close to us but we never felt unsafe at any point; it was a very tranquil and clam environment. As well as elephants, we saw alligators and an array of different birds too. A wonderful place to visit - not to be missed!

We wanted to see elephants in the wild during our trip to Sri Lanka and therefore visited Kadulla. We were very fortunate to see about 100 elephants during our visit but had serious concerns about the lack of respect from the 4x4 drivers who showed zero respect for these endangered animals. At one stage we stopped by a dry shallow ravine to watch a large (+60) elephants grazing on the opposite side. We were quickly joined by over 50 jeeps and then one of the drivers decided to venture to the other side, therefore splitting the herd in two. This jeep was quickly followed by the majority of the jeeps resulting in a stressed group of elephants. A large male was patrolling the edge of the herd and was obviously distressed. This presented a serious safety issue for the people nearest the front as the proximity of the jeeps was too close to these large animals. In summary, it was fantastic to see the elephants in the wild, however the park needs to reduce the number of jeeps allowed at one time and also set clear guidelines on distances and code of conduct for the drivers.

You have to go.  Some comments about the number of four by fours in the park but remember you are one of those making up the crowd. Sit back and enjoy the elephants. They do not appear to notice the traffic.

We enjoyed the view of the lake and the huge groups of elephants (including very little ones). We disliked the fact that the drivers - most likely to please their clients - really 'chase' the elephants to get a good view. there was a male elephant that was really distressed by the fact he was cornered by 4 jeeps trying to get the best picture. This is not respectful for the animals and is literally an accident waiting to happen.
Great experience to see elephants in their habitat, though there were more jeeps than elephants! Still very much worth a visit!

We went to this national park with Rana's information centre (found on the Main Street of Habarana) and they were friendly from the beginning, and made sure we had a fantastic time in the park. As there were only two of us, they helped us find another pair to fill the jeep to get it for a cheaper price. Overall the park is amazing, we saw over 100 elephants and they were so peaceful. And would recommend booking with Rana'!
This time is an ideal time to see elephants in their natural habitat as they should be witnessed rather than riding them. Amazing beasts.
Many tourists but many elephants too! Best to enter the park at around 16:00. Water buffalos and nice birds too. Nice nature around.

It is absolutely wonderful to see elephants in their natural habitat, but I have to ask when is the number of safari vehicles in a park to much. On the day we visited there was at least 200 vehicles and not all of them adhered to the distance rules. This is a true wonder which will be destroyed by commercial tourism.See this wonder before it is destroyed by commercialism.

We were Lucky to be jeep nr. 11 and have some quiet moments in the park but after half an hour (15:00) more and more jeeps entered the park. Lots of drivers did not keep any distance  at all and at a certain moment a group of 15 mothers and their youngs were surrounded by more then 30 jeeps. I felt very sorry for the elephants and asked our driver to head for the exit.  We passed ar least another 50 jeeps so when we left there were more then 150 jeeps in the park chasing the same group of elephants. I instantly decided to skip Uda Walawe. Never ever again.
We saw two herds totalling 80-90 elephants during our visit to Kaudulla National Park. We actually saw more here than in Ude Walawawe NP. Would highly recommend a visit!

Went with family in late July. Plenty of elephants. Though Animals are well behaved, not the people who manage the place as they seems to be lost. Lots of Jeeps (from Tricomalee road entrance (It is not the only entrance I suppose) and they find it difficult to manage it. i cannot understand why people are allowed to get down from vehicles inside the park. Day by day, Minneriya, Yala and now Kaudulla are becoming very difficult to visit due to this jeep maniac.  Anyhow you forget everything when you see the park with elephants. What a beautiful national park.
It's true, you're not the only jeep in the park, but the drivers keep  enough distance, and with some luck, you can end the day near the lake watching the animals relax

The literature on this park boasts elephants, sloth bears, deer and all sorts of birds. We were travelling with friends, so there were four of us in one vehicle. We started off down a very long road next to a river and for the first fifteen minutes saw one macaque and one bird. Then we came out of the woodland and saw a golden jackal in the road then onto a lake where there were loads of safari jeeps all at the lakeside surrounding a herd of elephants. We manoeuvred our way to a nice viewpoint and stayed a while taking lots of pictures. There must have been about thirty jeeps all around the lake watching various small herds of elephant, some with young only about a month old. We moved among them taking loads of photos until it was time to leave, after about two hours. The sun was starting to set and we loitered a little too long taking pictures of the sunset and got mock charged twice by elephants who wanted to let us know that it was now their people free time, and to keep moving - so we did.  The elephants are accustomed to lots of vehicles around them but you can see that they are feeling pressured, especially at the end of the day when they want rid of the tourists.  Most of the drivers were very respectful of the wildlife. We didn't go at the peak of season so I would be concerned for the elephants welfare at that time.
We saw hundreds of elephants and the scenery was nice. However, the number of jeeps spoilt our visit. It felt like being at a zoo rather than being in the wild.

We were picked up at our accomodation by our jeep booked by the Hideout Guest House. We arrived and had to line up for 45 minutes to purchase a ticket from a ticket booth manned by 2 men with only one serving. When I paid the ticket salesman attempted to shortchange me by 3000 Rupee. I informed the tour guide who questioned the man who quickly gave back the 3000 without explanation to me. I asked the tour guide what he said and was told he forgot. It was straight out stealing and combined with the line up to buy the tickets was a disappointment. The safari was great but we didn't get inside the park until 2 hours after we were picked up. We saw lots of elephants near the lake side which was fantastic. There are loads of other jeeps all in the same area at the same time which is a shame. The kids loved it and so did we...logistics and thriving aside. The trip cost about $90 US all up including the pick up truck. Great for families, especially young kids. Take a good camera as there are many great photo ops.
Top safari to see elephants wander to the pond in the afternoon ok price $90 with a  family 2 adults and 2 childeren 7 and 5 years old

This National park is known for it's herds of Elephants and it certainly didn't disappoint. We found a couple of solitary elephants but once our guide found a large tusker he knew better was to come. We were driving around a large stand of trees and there they were directly in front of us about 300m away and walking towards us. Animals of all ages with a number of very young suckling from their mothers. It was great to see how protective of the young the older elephants were. We saw a herd of about 40 but there obviously more as we could see movement still in the trees. This park is not near as touristy as other parks such as Yala and on this occasion we were 1 of only 2 jeeps with this herd of elephants. The tracks in this park were very good probably due to the small amount of traffic compared to far more popular parks.
We where lucky to see many elephants here. Its a great tour. But its better to ask where the elephants are because they travel between the parks.

Now I'm Indian and I ideally take elephant sighting for granted ..but not here Watching them in the wild...the Lone Ranger ... then the massive herds of anywhere between 50 to 70 which we sighted here... the little baby ones closer to their mum Eating in the wild pulling out grass .. dusting it off before mouthing it.. spraying themselves with mud to keep cold I guess.. protecting the babies...alert of the jeeps around n conscious of human sounds The jeep safaris to watch the elephants was great A tip..the hotel could organise it for about 30 to 50 dollars or u could walk the street n find a local tour guide .. we paid as low as $22 Important.... respect the wild n the forces of this wild creature.. we enter into their habitat .. they r with little ones n like it peaceful If the guide asks u to keep silent... keep silent

Great experience in the national park. Not very touristy when we visited. Driver found elephants so it felt like a real Safari. Sighted peacocks and foxes. Great trip. Booked through our small hotel, great price.

Difficult to write a review because the experience was both beautiful and terrifying. The park has all the potential to offer a great experience, with a 99% chance to see at least a few elephants in isolation, but big change to see herdes. The experience was great untill our guide repeatedly drove the jeep to close to the elephants, resulting in them approaching the jeep agitated and trumpeting and the jeep speeding off to safer distance. This went on a few times untill the jeep driver went off track and we got completely stuck on a huge rock with 3 angry male elephants storming towards the jeep. At the last few meters of them reaching the jeep they finally got scared from the sound of the roaring engine and they turned towards bushes 40 meters from the jeep. When the aggressive trumpeting continued and all other (30!) elephants in the bushes joined in. It took about 15 minutes and mostly the initiatives of the 3 other tourists (men) in the jeep to get the jeep freed from the rock. All in all, the park had all the potential to cater for an amazing experience, but this was so scary I could not enjoy.
Yala is such a better place than this.  Kaudulla for us was such a rip off and what we saw at Yala was tenfold.

Great jeep tour of the park in the afternoon. My son counted about 140 elephants that day. We got to see them closeup and there weren't too many other jeeps in April. Standing in the open top jeep, observing the elephants was amazing. Saw a lot of elephants on the road and fields on the way back to our hotel too. Would highly recommend this trip to others. One of the highlights of our trip. Enjoyed it much more than our 2 jeep trips in Yala.

It is beautiful forest filled with greenary and wild animals. There are elephants,deers,peacocks,jackals and different kinds of birds. If you want to see lot of elephants you should go early morning. Take water. While travellin in the safari jeep beware of the branches.

We visited the park on 14th April 2017. The jeep driver was knowledgeable and fairly careful in his driving.  The park was not very crowded compared to Yala NP standards. Basic facilities at the entrance was acceptable though the park management could do a better job at beautifying the entry and visitor information areas. The park seemed well maintained with good tracks. However, the best thing about the park are the elephants including many baby elephants. Kaudulla is one of the best places to see elephants and even get the experience of being chased by one!! Our jeep and a few others were chased by a bull elephant. Of course this is not a major safety concern and happens often at the park, Jeep drivers know their driving and usually gets the jeep out of the harms way. If you are visiting Sri Lanka and love elephants, Kaudulla National Park is a must visit. There are many other historical attractions nearby such as Sigiriya rock fortress, Dambulla rock temple, Minneriya National Park and close to excellent hotels at Kandalama near Dambulla and Sigiriya.

We had a lovely time here.  Only a small park but plenty of birds and absolutely loads of elephants.  You can get quite close to them should you so wish.  Not a lot of people around.  Really good for bird watching.

Our tour though Kaudulla NP by Jeep was one of the highligts of our trip throuhg Sri Lanka! We have never seen that many elephants at once, being so close. WE coud have watched them feeding grass so peaceful for ages! There ware also little ones, always being sheltered by their mum - very georgous! We also came across a very big herd of bufflons and a lot of birds. That was just an amazing tour!

This is how to see elephants in Sri Lanka! Do not ride them or visit the so-called orphanages. Here are elephants in the wild... with babies! The views are amazing and the drivers know all the great places to catch more than a glimpse of these magnificent animals without ending up in an unseemly crush of vehicles. We loved every minute of it!
We had an open top jeep and one of the official Park rangers as a guide. It was really excellent. Saw loads of elephants including babies. Great bird life and various turtles, bison etc.
We had a great afternoon at Kaudulla! Saw so many elephants in the wild, it was quite a sight! Many colorful birds as well and beautiful scenery.

This was one on the hi-lights of our trip to Polonnaruwa. The jeep driver new where to go and we ended up getting very close to wild elephants. During the 3 hour safari we have seen over hundreds elephants. Well worth the trip.

My favourite part of the whole trip - there were A LOT of jeeps, however the general consensus from the drivers was to not crowd too much and move on after a short while.. I did two safari's and both the drivers were very conscious of how many jeeps were around the elephants or if there were too many. The elephants are very at ease with the cars, some walk quite close by, otherwise it was simple breathtaking just sitting back and watching 40+ wild elephants just doing their own thing.

Although there were many jeeps this evening, we were able to get very close to the mothers and babies.  Please, fellow animal-lovers, DO NOT BRING BALLOONS AND SHAKE THEM SCREAMING FOR THE ANIMALS' ATTENTION.  Let's show our humanity.

I would recommend that you leave it to your driver to decide whether you go to Kaudulla or Minneriya as they are close to each other and the guides know where the elephants are likely to appear. Yes, there are a lot of jeeps but when the engines are switched off watching these wonderful animals in the wild is a joy. There are of course other animals and a good selection of birds.

Our Chauffeur- Guide knew there was a large herd of female and juvenile elephants in the park so as we were nearby we headed there the following morning. We were not disappointed as we observed over a 100 elephants eat and swim in the reservoir unperturbed by all that watched and were enthralled by them. We also saw a large bull elephant who was circling the her and on one occasion came a little too close to our jeep but I got a good photo!
Great jeep safari to see elephants, monkeys, peacocks, fish eagles and other wild birds in their natural habitat. Tracks are bumpy but nothing that the jeep couldn't handle. Amazing experience!

Undoubtedly there are better safaris e.g. Yala, but if you want elephants then Kaudulla by our experience is a good place to start. We saw over 50 elephants, 6/7 herds as well as water buffalo, wild fox and plenty of bird life. Indeed, we actually saw wild elephant at the roadside before we got to the park. Our guide appeared knowledgeable enough and his English sufficient to get by.

We went to this park rather than Mineriyah as it would in theory be less busy. Unfortunately there were a good number of jeeps which spoiled the experience somewhat. Nevertheless we did see a number of different species of birds and lots of elephants. Very enjoyable if you are an elephant fanatic like me!.
The view of elephants in the wild is great and the biggest draw, however we also saw birds of prey and a Kingfisher.

i have never seen such a elephants in a national park i have ever visited. baby elephants are walking with  there parents it a unforgettable experience i have ever had............................................

We arranged for the safari through our hotel at Sigiriya. The 4X4 jeep arrived at 2 pm but we could started only at 2.30 as we climbed the Rock Fortress. It was an hour drive before we entered the National Park. Our Driver Sarath was a wnder ful guide and took us through the tracks where we could see monitors, monkeys and different birds before we came on an expanding grassland leading to a huge lake. Here we saw quite a good number of birds including egrets and pelicans. Peacocks are of course in abundance like any other place in India and sri Lanka. Once we take a turn around the lake we came across the first elephant. it was a huge tusker and  was alone. So, the driver didn't go too close and we saw it from a distance of about 300 mt. within next half an hour we saw some more elephants and they were in small herds of 8-10. After that we came across our prized catch for the day - a herd of about 40-50 elephants including at least 5 baby elephants. And at that very moment it started raining heavily. Seating inside the jeep and watching those gentle giants playing in the rain was an unforgettable experience. About 10 jeeps dared to wait there in that torrential rain and observe the herd for around 15 minutes. After that driving out of that grassland in the rain was another experience for which the entire credit goes to Sarath who also helped another driver to pull off his jeep from mud on our way back. On our way back we were gifted again with a riot of colors on the sky painted by the setting sun. Great experience
Pretty good place to see elephants. I was a little worried with so many jeeps close to the herd but they were totally unfazed by it.

We were due to visit Minneriya Park, but our driver knew where the elephants were and took us to Kaudulla, a neighbouring reserve. We picked up a young bird expert at the gate and he had eyes like the proverbial hawk. He and the driver worked hard to ensure that we saw a wide range of birds and wildlife. The group of elephants we came across were almost within touching distance, a real thrill. It's not as busy a park as the famous Yala and the drivers seem more relaxed. We went in the afternoon yet the wildlife and birds were out in force. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience.

This is a quick safaris to get to see elephant. Do not expect to see a whole lot more unless it is on route to the elephant. The evening tour is the best time. The safaris vehicles go in their masses and all head in the same direction, the banks of the lake to see the herd/s, if you are lucky, of elephant. Great fun and a safari with a difference. We also saw water buffalo, peacocks, pelicans, painted storks and some other birds.

We visited the park in march in early afternoon. Apart from two groups of elefant we saw some buffalos and some birds Cost was 5000 LKR entrance fee and we payed 4.000LKr for the jeep. So roughly 65 USD

My host organised the safari for me. The entrance ticket costs 3450 rupees and expect to pay 3500-4000 for your jeep. The trip was incredible. Not only because I saw herds of elephants and buffaloes but because of the nature and the sounds around. It was an incredible experience. Make sure you get a decent jeep-there was one with diesel problems, luckily just outside the park.

We did there an afternoon safari, the place is beautiful and we saw many elephants. The elephants here are wild and leave free in the jungle, you don't get very close to the animals as other places with domesticated elephants but the experience is much better here!

We were not expecting the number of elephants we saw there.. The drive through the park stading in the jeep with no foolish health and safety laws.. But just the chance to really enjoy the experience. We saw one set of elephants. Probably about 50.. Walking towards the water. Going after lunch, around 3pm is a good time. Might see the occasional alligator and a few birds of paradise. Overall, can't wait to go back.

In a 3 hour tour of the park we saw 3 different herds of elephants.  What majestic creatures they are!  Our guide, Pradeep, and driver were excellent spotters so we saw birds, a sloth bear, 2 different mongoose  breeds and assorted other wild things. Roads were rough!  Bathroom facilities primitive.

We had planned to visit the Minneriya national park and had booked a hotel in Habarana  close to Minneriya entrance. Our hotel (Sanoga Resort, Moragaswewa, Habarana, 50150), who arranged a jeep with driver for the safari, advised us that elephants were seen in th Kaudulla Park rather than the Minneriya. We were picked up from our hotel. Kaudulla is a bit further than Minneriya but it was worth it. We saw two lots of elephant heards and also lots of different birds including Flamingos and peacocks dancing. The tour follows a large lake inside the park and the path is a bit rough. We paid Rs. 7500 for the jeep as well as the park entrance fees. On our way back we saw elephants from the main road! Next day we visited Polonnaruwa; the road goes past the Minneriya lake and there too we saw a couple of elephants bathing from the road.

We had a late afternoon safari here and were pleased by it. Often it is a tourist trap only interested in making a fast buck. The driver knew his job and managed to bring us up and close to many elephants. Amazing experience

It was a amazing to see the migrating elephants at close quarters. The tour guide was knowledgeable and kept calm when one rather large elephant looked like he was going to charge at our jeep! The downside is there were over 50 jeeps viewing the elephants which I think was stressing some of them out. It was a stunning setting and one of the highlights of our 2 week tour.

That is the best place, where I saw over 500 wild elephants, in an area of less than ten sq.kms. They were scattered in about 5 or 6 areas, roughly from 75 to about 125 at each place, but not far from each other. The elephants  come close as ten meters, but never attacked the Jeep, I was in. There were more than 20 or 25 other vehicles. Need about three hours, but must hire a 4WD jeep, which are readily available near all hotels in Habarana, and cost about Rs. 3500 to Rs. 4000 (which is about US$30 to $35 only). Need to buy an entrance ticket, lower rate for the locals, & about $10 for the foreign visitors.

Our guide took us here instead of Minneriya due to the Elephant movements. We were able to see several groups of elephants including baby elephants and some bathing. We chose to see elephants here, happy and free instead of Pinnewela Orphanage which we feared may exploit the elephants.

We saw mostly elephants, but we had the most amazing driver and he got us very close even to the smallest ones. :) He knew very much about the animals and exatcly which ones could get angry at us. So very close distance observation was possible still being safe. An amazing day!!!!

This park was more touristy than we would  have liked, but it was the only way to see elephants in the wild.  We saw one family and a couple of individual males. There were also painted storks, peacocks, other birds, and water buffalo.  The setting is very pretty as well.  We had some excitement when our driver decided to rescue another jeep that got itself stuck in the mud/water.  It took a team effort but they finally prevailed.  No one left behind!
